column3: Recommended for anyone who enjoyed the Settlers
column4: Stronghold and Cultures series. Might interest those that like base-building as this RTS is more focused on the Economy. The game comes with both Shattered Kingdom and Peasant Rebellion Expansion. The Multiplayer is still active! And might even be a challenge for those wanting to get competitive (See note below)  Example: To recruit units you have to first make their equipment from raw materials. For a swordman you need to make a sword
column5: a shield and an armor. To make those you need to mine iron and smelt it
column6: additionally you will need coal for your smelting and forging. Finally you can turn a recruit into a Swordman.  All-in-all this game is a staple in old-school RTS where there is a focus on the economics. Those who enjoyed Northgard might also find this game interesting barring the graphics.  *NOTE* To run this game on modern machines go download the free HD remake called KaM Remake at  http://www.kamremake.com/  The HD patch will let the game run in window mode and can also stretch to widescreen resolution  This game goes on discount quite often
column7: give it a go if you like old-school RTS games

column3: Lux Delux is a Risk style game
column4: similar in many ways to the original but with several extra features. Although the game mechanics are very simple
column5: the strategy is often quite challenging.   https://youtu.be/DTupYOTo90Q  Probably the most outstanding feature of this game is that there are over 900 maps available
column6: providing endless variety in the gameplay. Most of these are created by users so the quality varies widely
column7: but there are more than enough good maps to keep you occupied.   https://youtu.be/vkfetLs8z0g  Another great feature is the AI
column8: which is really well programmed. There's around a dozen bots of different difficulty levels
column9: each of which has a different playstyle. The hard bots are REALLY tough to beat! Additionally there's multiplayer so there's plenty of humans to go up against.  Graphics are pretty basic
column10: but they're perfectly functional for this kind of game. Many of the maps are really well designed.  It's a fairly quick game to play
column11: although it can take longer on some bigger maps or against tougher opponents
column12: so it's great for when you have 10 or 20 minutes to spare.  I recommend this for anyone who craves a quick strategy fix but doesn't have enough time for a full game of Civ 5 or Hearts of Iron 3!

column4: being a fan of the Cultures series I have to admit that the dumbed down mechanics are just horrible. Vikings just fall out of from the sky
column5: and the game has been so streamlined that all you have to do is just mass-manufacture axes and head for the gate. It feels like a half???????product and moreover the devs are trying to get money for DLCs only add biomes to the randomly generated maps which are by themselves lackluster.  Despite buying this game on release
column6: and rooting for it. I cannot recommend purchasing the game in its state. It feels incomplete and has no storyline. You just repeat the same thing over and over again
column7: which is try to get to the gate and accumulate karma points...

column3: The Crew is a multiplayer always-online arcade-racer set in a huge open world which is a condensed version of the United States. It was designed by many of the same people who created Test Drive Unlimited
column4: so it can effectively be thought of as TDU 3. It contains many of the same features
column5: but not all (no houses or shops).   http://youtu.be/CBYh4vPmH2k  I think many people are unfairly critical of this game
column6: and are failing to appreciate the best feature
column7: the huge open world. In reality
column8: the world area is only around 5000 sq km (about a quarter of the size of Wales)
column9: yet that's still a huge size for a game world
column10: possibly the second largest open world racing game (Fuel is over twice as big). Road wise
column13: 10 times as much as in the first TDU game
column14: so that will take a long time to explore properly. But it's not just the size of the world that's impressive
column15: it's the attention to detail and the huge number of landmarks. It's extremely well designed.  The USA is not only condensed
column17: some areas are much larger than others. This is necessary since if everything was to scale
column18: every city would be a tiny village. Instead
column19: the biggest cities are made much larger
column20: as well as features like the Grand Canyon
column21: while less interesting areas are shrunk in size. The result is greatly distorted
column22: but it feels really good to drive around
column23: and I believe it does a good job of representing the "highlights" of the USA in a way which suits a computer game very well.   https://youtu.be/vNx4FtHofwU  Many people have complained about the horrible car physics. I was a bit shocked at this too in the beginning
column24: but it turns out that the early cars handle badly by design
column25: and get much better as you upgrade them with parts. The few cars I've tried from the DLCs handle much better. It also takes a little while to tweak your wheel or controller settings to get it to feel good
column26: but it's worth the effort.   http://youtu.be/KksGtk6F-i8  Apparently rubber banding is also a problem in the game
column27: although I did read someone say it's been fixed. I've noticed it a few times with police chases
column28: but it doesn't seem to be much of a problem to me. Speaking of police chases
column29: I find them to be a lot of fun
column30: while others seem to hate them. Similarly
column31: the raid challenges can be quite frustrating
column32: but are also fun to me. Depends on your point of view I suppose.  The GPS tends to provide the shortest route between two points
column33: which is often not the best way to get to where you want quickly (taking you through backstreets instead of sticking to main roads)
column35: SatNav does that in real life too! Just think of it as a guide that you don't have to stick to. Learning the main roads and using your "local knowledge" instead can save time! Also it tends to suggest offroad shortcuts
column36: which can be annoying if you want to stick to roads
column38: it gives you a route through difficult scenery which you might otherwise get stuck in.  One annoying thing I have noticed is graphical glitches during the cut scene intros to most missions. Don't know what's causing this
column39: but it's only a minor irritation
column40: it doesn't happen when I'm driving.  Another slight peeve is that much of the terrain is too destructible
column41: you can drive straight through lamp posts and other features as if they weren't even there
column42: yet some are rock solid. It's sometimes hard to know which is which. Okay
column43: so it's just an arcade game so you could say it's excusable
column44: but it does lead to bad driving habits
column45: driving through obstacles that you'd normally avoid. In fact
column46: to win certain missions it's often a good idea to crash through things.   https://youtu.be/blIdOUmGMh8  Same goes for crashing into other cars
column47: often (not always) this has little or no effect
column48: barely slowing you down in most instances. Again
column49: I don't like this because it encourages bad driving habits
column50: not caring about hitting other cars when normally you should try to avoid them at all costs. But again
column52: so I can live with it.  Sure
column53: there are a few faults with this game
column54: but most of them hardly matter to me. The game world is so large
column55: with so many places to go
column56: so many things to see (there's educational info on historical landmarks) and so many cars to drive (not a huge selection
column57: but there are many variants of each
column58: and who needs hundreds of cars anyway?) that I'm having too much fun cruising and exploring to take much notice of the faults. I think if people focused less on the faults and concentrated more on the fun aspects of the game
column59: they'd enjoy it a lot more.  For me the FreeDrive mode is the real game
column60: going on road trips solo or with friends. I dont' really care about the missions and the story that much (although they do add a nice bit of character to the game)
column61: I just want to explore America!  Having said that
column62: the game gets more interesting the deeper you get into it. As you level up you unlock factions and faction missions
column63: and that adds a lot more fun to the game
column64: not to mention money! Some say that money is hard to come by and there's a lot of grinding
column66: money is easy to make. It's not a "pay to win" game
column67: you can pay if you're lazy
column68: but you can make it easily enough by simply playing the game.  I'm really enjoying The Crew and I highly recommend it to positive gamers who enjoy exploring a huge open world
column69: who don't mind the arcadey gameplay and can live with a few faults. Be sure to get the Gold Edition or buy the Season Pass to get a bunch of good cars that unlock fairly early in the game
column70: to give you a decent variety of cars to go free roaming in
column71: otherwise you'll be stuck with the early cars for a while.  Negative focused nit-pickers need not apply!

column3: I finally put a lot of hours into CAU last night
column4: going through all 12 of the new police missions
column6: doing several crate delivery missions (as a bad guy) and joining in several police chases (to stop the bad guy). I also levelled up to 60 in the process.  My opinion is that the new chases are great fun. They add a new dimension to the gameplay
column7: which frankly has become a little stale after 500+ hours in the game. The police chases freshen it up a lot. It's much more exciting to be chased by real players than the AI police
column8: while chasing down and arresting real players is extremely satisfying.  However
column9: the DLC is very poor value for money
column10: unless you don't own Wild Run
column11: in which case it's great value for money because you get both. If you've already purchased Wild Run
column12: then it's a bit of a rip off. They really should have sold it at a discount for Wild Run owners.  The good news: you don't have to own CAU to be a criminal and do the crate delivery missions
column13: so everybody gets half of the new content for free!  The bad news: there are only 12 new missions and the story is pretty much non-existent. Unlike the original story missions there are no cut-scenes for most of them
column14: so we don't even get to see the bad guy we're after. We're just chasing a name. The missions don't take long to complete
column15: I did them all in an hour or so
column16: and I got no sense of satisfaction or connection to the so called story. I expected a lot more
column17: like the original story that was much more engaging.  Having said that
column18: the new missions are a lot of fun and I spent a lot of time repeating many of them
column19: trying to score platinum in each. That's a very quick way to level up your police cars. Due to the nature of the chases
column20: they can be different each time. In fact
column21: doing badly is more fun than catching them quickly because you get a longer chase to enjoy.  The real fun though
column22: is chasing (or being chased by) real players rather than the idiot AI who are usually quite easy to beat (except on the harder missions). And of course
column23: there are a few new cars available and being a cop in supercar is really cool.  In summary: It's a lot of fun and I'm really enjoying it
column24: but it's very poor value for money if you already own Wild Run. If you love this game
column27: why not? If you don't have Wild Run
column28: it's very good value. If you're on the fence

RaceRoom is an excellent sim racer made by the same people behind Simbin
column4: makers of Race 07 and other great sims. It's worthy of serious consideration by everyone who loves sim racing. Don't be fooled by the many bad reviews
column5: there's a good reason for them
column6: which I'll explain later. There's also more good news later.   https://youtu.be/itBXrA2QEEM   http://youtu.be/I7URfx-CpwE  Raceroom offers a large collection of cars (75 in total) and tracks (25 in total
column7: many of which have several different layouts) and 3 competitions (2 DTM and ADAC) which are called "Experiences". These Experiences give you full seasons with teams and drivers. In short
column8: there's a lot of variety in this game.  I haven't put many hours into this game yet
column9: but so far I've found the racing "experience" to be extremely good. Physics are very realistic and the AI seems pretty good too. One very nice feature is the ARI (Adapative Racing Intelligence) which adjusts the difficulty level automatically to match your skill and experience. At first I wasn't impressed with this since the AI drivers were driving too slowly
column10: but apparently the difficulty level starts low and increases over time. After a few races the AI had adapted to my level and started to provide some decent competition without being overly difficult to beat.  There are three racing modes; Novice
column11: Amateur and Get Real. Novice is a bit of a joke since it actually brakes for you as you approach the corners. Amateur has realistic physics
column13: ABS and zero damage. Get Real turns the driving aids off (but damage is still optional). It's a pity I couldn't configure all these things separately
column14: I'd like to have driven on Amateur level but with damage turned on for example.  Now the bad news...  Many people have criticised this game for being free to play but with very little content. That's true
column15: but what do you expect for free? You get 5 different cars and 3 tracks (each with several variations)
column16: more than enough to evaluate the quality of the game and give you some great racing fun for no more than the price of the download.  Think of it this way
column17: the "free to play" game is just a demo
column18: the REAL game is in the addon packs. Three of the DLCs currently available on Steam are "Experiences" - full seasons with tracks and cars - DTM 2013 and 2014
column19: ADAC 2014. It actually makes more sense to buy these as DLCs rather than buying a whole new game every year
column20: as with the F1 games. The fourth DLC is just a car pack
column21: not an "Experience".  Here's where the problems begin...  The three Experience DLCs contain a lot of duplicate content. They mostly use the same tracks and some of the same cars. For example
column22: the two DTM packs only have 1 track and 1 car different. This makes buying all the DLCs a waste of money
column23: because you're paying for mostly the same content that you've already bought.  To confuse matters even more
column24: there are many more packs you can buy that aren't available as Steam DLCs
column25: as well as individual cars and tracks
column26: some of which are not available in any packs. You can buy them in-game or from their website. These are bought using the in-game currency of vRP points
column27: so you can't see what they cost in real money. However
column28: if you add the items to your cart you can see the cost.  I created a spreadsheet to show what's available in each pack
column29: which you may find helpful;   http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=445609150  Whoever came up with this ridiculous marketing/sales model should be fired. It confuses buyers and can result in wasted money buying duplicate content. Judging by the number of negative reviews
column31: which is a pity. I hope they don't go bankrupt again because of this!  Fortunately
column32: there is some good news...  While experimenting with adding various packs to the cart on their website
column33: I discovered that they DON'T CHARGE FOR DUPLICATE CONTENT! They know what cars and tracks you own
column34: so you don't pay extra for what you already have. So if you already own DTM 2013
column35: DTM 2014 will be cheaper as a result. I wanted to buy all the tracks but was loathe to buy the European Track Pack for just one extra track
column36: but when I added it to my cart
column37: it cost less than a pound extra
column38: less than half the price of buying that track individually!  So
column39: it's okay to buy ONE Experience pack from Steam
column40: but if you want any more
column41: buy them from their site instead. Also
column43: you won't be charged for it.  Even more good news
column44: the more packs you buy at one time
column45: the cheaper they get. There's a cumulative discount
column46: so if you're going to buy any packs
column47: buy as many as you can afford to save more money. I bought 7 items and got a 16% discount. If you buy all the packs I think you get a discount of around 30%  To give you an idea of cost
column48: I spent less than ?30 to get all the tracks and about a third of the cars. I could have gotten all of the tracks cheaper than that
column49: but I wanted some extra cars as well. Two tracks are not contained in any pack. Buying all the packs would cost around ?70 I think
column50: but unless you're a collector who has to have everything
column51: it doesn't need to cost that much.  CONCLUSION: I highly recommend this game to all sim racers. Those who prefer casual or arcade racing should probably avoid this game (but by all means try the "demo" first). The DLCs
column52: packs and points method of selling this game is overly complex and confusing
column53: but if you like this game
column54: don't be put off by that
column56: and it's much cheaper to buy the extras direct from the game or their website

column3: In this game you play as the goddess Athena
column4: who's job it is to guide Odysseus' boats to safety. You do this by altering the wind strength
column5: which always blows toward their destination
column6: and by dragging your mouse through the sea to create currents.  This sounds simple enough
column7: but you also have to prevent the ships from hitting rocks and sand bars
column8: and avoiding other dangers like a cyclops throwing rocks at them (you can catch the rocks by clicking on them with the mouse). Additionally you need to direct the boats to statues to unlock gates and there are also bonuses to pick up along the way. Naturally it gets harder as you progress
column9: with newer dangers and more difficult maps to negotiate.  Although the graphics are pleasing
column10: the resolution is only 640x480. You have a choice of full screen or windowed.  To be honest
column11: it's not my type of game and it didn't hold my interest for very long
column12: but it's by no means a bad game. It wouldn't appeal to everyone
column13: but it's fairly challenging and I'm sure some gamers would enjoy it.  Conclusion: a decent casual game ideal for a quick play when you don't have much time to spare.

column3: Drizzlepath: Genie is a walking simulator that takes you on a journey through beautiful scenery. The rain soaked atmosphere is very relaxing. It's not as dark as Dear Esther. The colours are quite muted
column4: but that's appropriate for an overcast day. The landscape contains various locations and objects of interest and it's worth looking around to find things you might otherwise miss.  Occasional voice narration enhances the experience. It's extremely poetic and descriptive
column5: painting pictures in words to further enhance the visuals. There's also relaxing music providing a soundtrack to your journey. It's pleasant enough to listen to but can get repetitive at times. I usually turn music off once that happens (which it does with all games)
column6: and often play without music or replace it with music of my own choice. It would be nice to have that option added. It's enjoyable enough just listening to the rain IMO.  There are many excellent opportunities for screenshots in this game
column7: which can extend the gameplay time considerably. There's a control to zoom out to give a wider angle of view and another to crouch
column8: which can provide you with a different viewpoint. You can even change to a grainy
column9: monochrome view which gives a completely different look to the game
column10: and is good for "arty" screenshots.  In spite of the overcast sky
column11: sunlight does stream through gaps in the clouds. Unusually it shines from multiple directions. Perhaps this planet orbits multiple suns? This sunlight causes purple lens flare
column13: but sometimes I felt there was a bit too much of it and I wished I could turn it off. UPDATE: If you set filter effects to medium or low the lens flare will be disabled.  It may be worth noting that I have not experienced any of the micro-stutters than mrorange mentioned in his review.  I don't understand what everything means in this game because I haven't completed it yet. In fact
column14: I've only been exploring the green path so far (there are two different paths through the game)
column15: but after three hours I think I've experienced enough to write this review. I'll update it once I've played more. Unfortunately I suffer from motion sickness in first person games so I can't play them for too long without feeling ill. I also take loads of screenshots so it'll take me a lot longer to complete than if I simply walked through it all without stopping.  Overall this is a very pleasant visual and aural experience (rather than a game) which I recommend to anyone who enjoys simply walking around and looking at beautiful scenery. It's a treat to the senses and is ideal for relaxation when you feel like taking a break from more demanding games.  Disclaimer: a key was provided by the developer in return for an unbiased review
column16: which is the only kind of review I'm willing to write.

column4: being a fan of the Cultures series I have to admit that the dumbed down mechanics are just horrible. Vikings just fall out of from the sky
column5: and the game has been so streamlined that all you have to do is just mass-manufacture axes and head for the gate. It feels like a half???????product and moreover the devs are trying to get money for DLCs only add biomes to the randomly generated maps which are by themselves lackluster.  Despite buying this game on release
column6: and rooting for it. I cannot recommend purchasing the game in its state. It feels incomplete and has no storyline. You just repeat the same thing over and over again
column7: which is try to get to the gate and accumulate karma points...

column3: Flockers is an action puzzle game in much the same style as Lemmings
column6: so you know the pedigree is good.   https://youtu.be/YQXgOCYvZFg  For those who don't remember the classic Lemmings
column7: it was a game in which a number of "lemmings" (which looked more like human workers to me) were released and would walk through the landscape
column8: following each other like the archetypal lemmings
column9: blindly walking off cliffs to their death. Your job as the player was to guide the lemmings by giving specific instructions to them
column10: for example to build bridges or dig into the landscape
column11: in order to guide as many of them to safety as possible.  Flockers uses essentially the same concept
column12: but with sheep instead of lemmings. Appropriately so
column13: since sheep also have the habit of following one another. This time around
column15: you have to help them navigate through extremely dangerous factory complexes
column19: often with gory results as your mindless sheep stroll blindly into them.  Each level is a puzzle. They're large
column20: and get progressively more complicated as you progress through them. You can zoom in and out to get a better view of the puzzle you have to solve. Sheep may wander off in different directions
column21: you may meet more sheep along the way
column22: transporters teleport sheep to different locations and it can sometimes be a bit confusing to understand what's going on the first time you try a new level.  As you go through each level
column23: sheep step on buttons which activate machinery
column25: sometimes in a very bad way
column26: so you have to be very careful what you let them step on. They also encounter crates
column27: which when opened give you new abilities that you can assign to your your sheep. It may take a few attempts to figure out how to get through a level.  While you often need to get only one sheep to safety (in the early levels at least)
column28: getting more will score you more points
column29: as will doing it in a faster time. You also get a bonus for using fewer abilities. You can retry levels to get a better score
column30: and you can compare your score to your friends.  The levels are very detailed
column32: which can make it tricky to figure out how to solve them. But maybe that's the point
column33: distracting you with unimportant details. Fortunately
column35: you can pause it at any time
column36: giving you the opportunity to study the puzzle at your leisure. You still have to solve it in real time though
column37: giving commands to your sheep as they move. Pressing the right mouse button gives you a bigger "brush"
column38: enabling you to give commands to multiple sheep at the same time.  The graphics are very good
column39: and very gory as sheep get smashed and sawed
column42: which is rather amusing if you find that sort of thing funny. For this reason the game has an age rating. But if you don't like that sort of thing
column43: you can simply turn off the gore in the video options.  I haven't played this game for very long yet
column44: but my first impressions are very good. I'm finding it both challenging and amusing
column45: an enjoyable casual way to pass the time. The price is very reasonable and it's on sale at the moment
column46: so this is a great time to grab it if you're interested.

column3: Guidelines to enjoy the game: - Inherently enjoy WC3/SC/SC2 custom map Tower Defense Games - Wait for release server stress to get fixed  Review of the Game in Contrast to WC3 Mod - Respected the original game and its features and improved on them - UI and gameplay improvements to focus on towers - Graphical improvement and balance changes
column4: so far no useless towers or overpowered - Ranked System - Client Improvements - Reconnection and general polish  In Contrast to other TD-styled games - Unique twist
column5: watch your towers come to live and fight your enemies - Competitive
column6: has a Ranked system and game encourages teamplay

column3: Governor of Poker 2 is an enjoyable poker game set in the Wild West
column4: that offers more than just poker. There's a long campaign where you travel to different cities
column6: encounter a variety of different opponents (including notorious ones)
column9: you get to buy new hats!   https://youtu.be/obuXfORI8v0  A big feature of real poker is the tells on your opponents faces
column10: but in this game you don't see faces
column11: just hats! In spite of this
column12: the game does a pretty good job of giving different personalities to the characters through their voices and actions
column13: and there are tells in the form of comments they make and other information
column14: such as getting steamy when they lose.  A big part of the game is travelling to different cities and buying buildings
column15: which provide you with passive income. At first you can only make money from playing poker
column16: but once you own a reasonable number of buildings you have a steady income trickling in. The idea is to build up your reputation and take over different cities. You can borrow money from the bank if necessary
column17: or sell buildings if you have any
column19: you can buy new hats. New hats impart some personality to the players and allow you to enter new tournaments.  The gameplay is fairly fast paced
column20: it's an ideal game for a quick poker fix
column21: but I'm not sure whether the cards played are truly random and whether the AI cheats or not. Some reviews claim that it does. I'm not experienced at poker so I can't really tell
column22: but as a casual player the gameplay seems decent to me
column23: even though I find it pretty hard to win
column24: even on the standard level. The Telltale poker games are a lot more fun if you want personality and banter
column25: but for a simple poker fix
column26: this does the job and is better than other poker games I've tried. There's no multiplayer
column27: so look elsewhere if that's what you want
column28: but it provides a good single player experience  The graphics are fairly basic
column30: but they're functional and pleasant to look at. There are free versions of this you can play on the internet but this version
column32: provides more depth.  Overall I'd recommend this game for casual players
column33: especially because of the extra interest that the campaign provides. Serious poker players may want to look elsewhere though.

column3: This game is the spiritual successor to Transport Tycoon
column4: but brought up to date in full 3D glory. First impressions are very good. On the surface it looks just like Train Fever with ships and planes added
column5: but there's a lot more to it than that. It runs on a new game engine for a start
column6: which solves the worst problem of the previous game
column8: which could often be extremely frustrating. It's still not perfect
column10: with far more complex track connections possible.   http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=796614848  The scenery is a lot more detailed when you look closely at it
column11: with many more different buildings in the towns. The vehicle models are really well done
column12: and they become dirty and rusty over time. Distant scenery blends better into the background with a misty effect.  The most significant change is that they've done away with the 20 minute rule and replaced it with catchment areas
column13: which is probably more familiar in these types of games. Journeys can be of any length now
column14: but passengers still prefer quicker transport. With freight it doesn't matter so much
column15: especially with ships that can carry huge amounts of cargo but travel very slowly.  Along with that
column16: resources and products no longer move on their own
column17: instead you have to transport everything yourself and place stations in appropriate catchment areas to ensure that everything gets delivered to the right places. Industries now have more complex resource requirements. If part of the supply chain is missing it will grind to a halt. This makes the game more challenging compared to Train Fever
column18: in which you could provide partial transport routes and the AI would automatically fill in the gaps.  In keeping with the more complex industries
column19: there are now six different types of products that need to be transported to towns
column20: three to the commercial districts and three to the industrial districts. This makes things even more complex since you need to use more depots to ensure the town is well supllied
column21: although you apparently only need to supply one industrial and one commercial product (in addition to passenger transport) to help cities grow
column22: making the more complex industrial chains seem somewhat unnecessary.  Regarding money
column23: even on the easy level there can be a lot of time spent waiting to make a profit  from your lines before you can expand
column24: and the harder levels are much more difficult. If you prefer to build without limits
column25: you can apply a mod which removes money from the game
column26: but you don't get any achievements in that mode.  In addition to the main random game
column27: there are also two campaigns included
column28: one for Europe and one for the USA
column29: featuring several scenarios each. I haven't tried these myself
column30: but they provide you with a story and clear goals to win each scenario. They're probably a good way to help learn the game if you haven't played Train Fever previously.  To sum up
column31: Transport Fever can be very engrossing. Personally I'm finding it just as addictive as Civilization
column32: but instead of "one more turn" there's always one more line to create
column35: a line to update or some other problem to solve. "I'll just finish doing this then I'll go to bed
column36: but I need to sort out that problem first
column37: oh and there's that other thing I need to look at
column38: and while I'm at it..."  If you enjoy these types of games
column39: this is a no brainer. We've been waiting a very long time for a spiritual successor to Transport Tycoon. Many similar games have come and gone over the years
column40: but this is the first that truly deserves that accolade. It's the best game in the genre in my opinion.

column3: The single player game mode is the new city mode
column4: where factions vie for control and all are battling a common enemy. Money
column5: earned by completing story-based missions or contracts for a faction
column6: is used to purchase new units. Units are divided into squads that can roam around the city
column7: and regenerate when killed. Missions take place inside (or adjacent to) procedurally-generated buildings that offer good variety in tactics. Some levels lack satellite coverage (hiding enemy movement) or contain locked windows or doors that must be opened in specific areas. The city game is a fun enhancement to the core gameplay
column8: as the different alliances and mission types provide variety each play through. The tactical game has received improvements as well
column9: starting with a large roster of new unit types (including riot shield
column16: and turret). These new units open up more tactical possibilities in each game. Units can be instructed to focus on a certain portion of the map
column17: and a ¡°focus diamond¡± can be played for increased accuracy. Large levels can be traversed in fewer turns using the ¡°long turn¡± option. Keeping units still
column19: and aiming in the correct direction still results in the best outcomes. The computer opponents are smart (most of the time) and provide good adversaries. Of course
column20: online play is also available using simultaneous turn resolution and turns that can be submitted at your leisure. All of the previous game modes are available (extermination
column25: plus quicker one-turn challenges. Frozen Synapse 2 has enough significant content through the robust city mode
column27: and interesting new units to justify its existence.   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FSre1B_H3Og

column3: The game features three short campaigns (11 scenarios total) at various difficulties
column4: plus five sandbox maps; there are no random maps to extend the content. The goal is to make money by collecting resources
column5: transporting those resources to factories to produce goods
column6: then selling those goods. There are some multi-step production chains in the game (iron + oil > plastic + steel + engine > mower) that add complexity and require planning. However
column7: it is extremely difficult to turn a profit early on in each campaign scenario (the sandbox maps have infinite money)
column8: as goods do not earn enough money to offset the expensive monthly maintenance costs for the factories and mines required to make those goods. Oligopoly is a potentially interesting economic strategy game with intricate production chains ruined by poor early game balance in the campaign mode.   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7lx6HjTjOfU

column3: The game features a campaign that consists of a series of semi-random scenarios where you must construct defenses and and army to fend off enemies that will appear after a set period of time; once you lose
column4: you have to start over from the beginning so there is only one saved game slot. Workers are assigned to collect resources
column7: or constitute your army. Town size can be increased by building houses with wells nearby
column8: and food must be produced every four turns to support your population. Random events
column9: such as merchants that will trade resources for gold and monsters that attack before the end of the scenario
column10: mix things up mid-game. Combat is performed in real-time
column11: where units are given move and attack orders and use special abilities. Units will attack nearby enemies to reduce micromanagement. The AI is basic but only needs to be in a defensive game. Ultimately
column12: ValeGuard is a game of resource management
column13: assigning the correct number of workers to collect and produce the right goods in order to have enough troops and defenses to fend off the final attack. While the mechanics are somewhat repetitive
column14: there is flexibility regarding which weapons and resources to focus on. Overall
column15: ValeGuard is an enjoyable defensive strategy game with a management slant.   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lVnV-zqE-38

column3: It really pains me to leave a negative review on this. The art design and assets are top-notch and reeks W40K out of every orifice. Unfortunately the game itself isn't anywhere near as polished to the point of frustration.   - No dedicated servers. Matchmaker displays no ping or useful information whatsoever to tell you the quality of the host. Oh and if you disconnect
column4: crash or the host leaves you lose all progress/rewards. Not a good combo.   - Class information is impossible to find unless you know exactly where to look. In fact there is only one screen that displays what the various class abilities actually do. What screen you ask? The in-game loadout. Yes
column5: you actually have to start up a match if you want to read about the abilities! Furthermore this information is poorly displayed. You'd think you'd just see the class abilities and their icons and hover the mouse over them or something
column7: they're hidden under some kind of awkward "level up" system.   - Rewards are given out in a Lootbox(TM) fashion. Of course
column8: you don't have to buy them with money or anything but Lootboxes(TM) with a random reward for each level-up is a horrid way to hand out rewards even if you don't have to pay for it. I've not gotten a single useful thing for any of the classes I prefer. Woopee.   - No Single Player "level replay system". The campaign features various collectibles and not being able to easily select and replay a beaten Chapter is asenine
column9: quite frankly. You have to start the Campaign over entirely if you miss any of them since the game only has a few save slots and overwrites them with each new Chapter.

column3: Pros:   - A return to Dark Souls 1-type of exploration. Relies less on connected smaller areas like Dark Souls 2 and 3 but instead you have a very large enviroment to explore in which you unlock shortcuts to make traversing it quicker as you go. I very much prefer this style
column4: so it is a big plus.   - Enjoyable and meaty melee combat. I daresay it is even better than Dark Souls in some regards
column5: especially when it comes to the bigger and heavier stuff which feel properly impactful and while still slow they flow a lot better than the Greatweapons of Dark Souls.   - Controls perfectly fine with mouse and keyboard. We all know how notoriously bad the Dark Souls-series is on this point
column6: but The Surge definitely pulls it off flawlessly.   - Runs perfectly fine
column7: even on my gaming laptop which is in the middle-ground between "Minimum" and "Recommended" specs.   - POISE! PRAISE THE SUN! The type of exo-skeleton rig you are wearing has stat akin to Poise in Dark Souls
column8: only it actually matters - a lot! When you are wearing the lighter and more agile rigs
column9: you are often sent flying into the air if you are unfortunate enough to get hit by an enemy with a heavy weapon. Wearing the beefiest rigs will not only reduce the damage taken
column10: but keep your feet firmly planted on the ground!  Cons:   - No character creation whatsoever. Now this could be excused if the main character was written in such a way that his set of characteristics were central to the plot
column11: but not as much. There is one spoilerific characteristic he has at the start of the game
column12: but that could easily be given to anyone else. The role he plays could be filled by a myriad of different people.   - No online component whatsoever. Whether you loved it or hated it
column13: the multiplayer aspect is a huge part of the Soulslike-experience and it is definitely noticable in it's absence.   - Retains the dumbest gimmick from Lords of The Fallen: You won't get the "proper" boss weapon unless you defeat the boss while meeting a specific condition. There is no way to know what that condition is in-game as you are fighting them
column14: forcing you to either spoil the game for yourself by Googling all the bosses and what to do or to miss out on the good version of their weapon. While there is NG+ to let you fight them again
column15: the bosses can't be re-fought in your current NG.  Overall I'd still recommend the game because I feel the positives heavily

column5: which you can read about elsewhere
column6: I will point out some differences to the model archetype of the genre
column8: which I used to play both with real cards and online in the past.   In general
column9: deck building and duels are the major aspects of the game in both cases. Also
column10: both ESL and MTG Online offer the alternatives of casual and tournament battles against real players or a competent AI. However
column11: ESL adds stories that form the framework of series of AI battles
column12: one of which comes with the base game and one (?Dark Brotherhood¡°) can be obtained with real or ingame currency. I did not find the stories incredibly interesting
column13: they give you good bonus cards though. Additionally
column14: you can choose a profile picture from a lore-friendly selection
column15: connected with a certain voice and way to express yourself during a battle. You receive rewards and card upgrades from ?levelling up¡° by collecting game experience
column16: and your chosen race determines what kinds of creatures you are likely to receive this way - a nice touch for all those RPG fans who flock to ESL coming from Skyrim or The Elder Scrolls Online. So far

column18: I have to mention that in ESL
column19: there is no free card market like in MTGO
column20: where I spent quite some time and real money to get the rare cards I needed for a competitive deck
column21: and that was full of ugly bots as well. Instead
column22: you can break down cards to receive gems
column23: that can be used to buy cards
column24: a simple and clean process and the reason why it is to be labelled as a collectible card game rather than a trading card game.  The developers of ESL also prevented abuse and spam by replacing the formerly common free ingame chat (as you can use in MTGO) with a selection of eight verbal expressions
column26: which are voice acted according to your chosen profile character (see above). Even though this is somehow restrictive
column27: I think it is an intelligent solution to a common problem in all multiplayer games. I found these ?verbal emoticons¡° to be quite sufficient to have basic and polite human interaction. You can still invite your friends from real life or from Steam if they tell you their Bethesda account name in order to play with them
column28: which of course means you can use other chat channels for a nice conversation while you play ESL in a small window.  The most welcome feature in ESL that makes it impossible for me to enjoy MTGO ever again is the rune mechanic: As you lose health
column29: ?runes¡° are broken one after the other
column30: which lets you draw additional cards and in some cases (?prophecies¡°) even play them instantly and without spending magicka. This creates a balancing effect to the benefit of a losing player and makes the game dynamic more interesting. It also makes the attacker think twice before dealing minor damage to his opponent that just might give him a tactical option that could turn the game in his favour.  In ESL
column32: usually to eight creatures in total. In MTG

column36: which I did not enjoy. In fact

column41: you have to play land cards that give you mana every turn. This necessity means that approximately half your deck consists of land cards
column42: most of which are quite bland and boring. In ESL
column43: magicka is gained every turn without such lands
column44: and your magicka pool is increased automatically. This has two effects: One

column48: but no resource to use them because you had bad luck with the distribution of land cards.  You have almost complete freedom in how to build your deck

column3: I don't write enough reviews!  But since I've played the game for roughly 360 hours now I'd say it's fair to give a positive review towards early access.  So here are all the pros and what I find fantastic and great about this title.  - Great and fun zombie killing gameplay experience on all difficulties - Game offers good challenges! - Little to no bugs or issues that would destroy your gameplay experience. - 4 very different maps to play on that are also randomly generated
column4: so gameplay does not get boring or repetetive. - Community challenges that let you compete with other people scores - Extremely addictive as it does not get repetetive as quickly. - Great music
column6: effect sounds - Well polish UI and easy learning curve.  Here are some cons that need work on
column7: but they are not awful!  - Units can be cumbersome to use as they don't follow the orders you give them time by time - No control over towers in general. They pick units to shoot by random. You get just a little control by giving "priority"
column8: but that's about it. - Lack of different game modes - Lack of unit variety  Okay so all in all this game is well worth every penny you spend. I would say be careful as it can consume your time without a notice.  As this is an early access game
column9: I'd say it has been very well polish and absolutely fantastic title!   For everyone who loves games such as starcraft
column10: Age of Empire or warcraft 3? You'll love this one.  And I would 200% recommend this game to anyone.

The story was even better than I expected. You will become a blind dude in this game. There is a nice girlfriend right by your side. She has some issues with your relationship. Therefore
column4: you have to make it work again. If you fail this quest
column5: you will lose your love. It's around one hour long and it's beautiful. I just really have to recommend this game.

column3: People mostly seem to hate this game. But I actually enjoyed playing through.  Achievements in this game are terrible. Everything else seems to be awesome. Therefore: I'm giving a positive review.

This is the perfect sequel for a great game. The gameplay has improved in many ways. It has a really great interactive storytelling. There's multiple routes that you can take. This game will take you back to the past. I have to recommend buying this game.
No time for a full review but here's one for my repeated nomination of this game as GOTY
column4: since it came out of Early Access.  I'll start off by saying that this is the worthiest adaptation of Robinson Crusoe spirit in gaming by date and I expect this honor to last a long time since now still. There's a lot of specific praise I could give this game but most of it would spoil the discovery for a new player.  And discovery is key with this game
column5: as it grabs you by the gills (accidental pun aknowledged) and draws you in very soon after you start exploring its world
column6: even though right until the point I tried it ¡ª the game looked like a completely unassuming time-waster to me. It undersells itself a lot in the marketing materials and LPs and there are reasons to that. It really requires one to play it to understand its appeal. Rarely I encounter such a phenomenon and I've played countless games of all ilks.  This game is solidly in the top list of games I ever played in my entire life. I will always remember it as a masterpiece both in its own right and as an indie
column7: as well as a definition of a hidden gem.

Yet another early access game. A game on the Eclipse Engine
column4: and published by Free Reign Entertainment. Those 3 things shouldn't deter you you from buying though. Minicharge of Nacho Games has a proven track record in decent quality games such as Hawken. Even solo queuing is enjoyable
column5: but a lot more fun in a party. The lead dev is pretty active with the community and interacts in his stream. Seems pretty transparent when asked questions about the game. It's worth a shot if you like tactical team based gameplay. Main thing I do have an issue is it's only one round. Should maybe be a best of 7 at least.

column3: I lost countless hours in this game. Start playing and before you know it hours have passed while trying for all the stars.

You get to be a dog that somehow triggered a time machine and has to solve puzzles to get back to the right year. Puzzles range from turning water on to get a guard away from a door to finding a bomb to blow up a pile of rocks. It's a lot of finding objects to help you get to other objects. Has some serious potential imo. It's on Unity so it will run on pretty much any rig. Right now it is the 1984 level
column4: but Medieval Ages and other levels are in development. Definitely worth keeping an eye on or grabbing if you like puzzle games and/or just want to be a dog time travelling.     Cops and crowbars don't mix well btw :)     Here is some gameplay:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n8G9jciM_sE

column3: Amazing story. Interesting characters every step along the way. Great environments to explore. You rescue people along the way and need to make sure you have food and med kits to keep alive along your journey to all kinds of towns to deliver miscellaneous items. Never know what is going to be on the other side of each door. Need to know when to fight and when to run. Mistakes are not forgiven.
If you are a fan of the classic RTS games like C&C Red Alert
column5: etc this is for you. Easy to learn and hard to master. I haven't gotten around to multiplayer or co-op yet
column6: but so far the main campaign is great. Steadily readies you for later battles as it introduces new units and buildings each mission.   It has your standard destroy all enemy buildings and survive x amount of minutes. Each mission has 3 difficulties that add harder objectives along with harder enemies. So there is plenty to do in single player to get familiar with the game before jumping headfirst into multiplayer.  I definitely recommend this to casual and hardcore RTS fans.  If you want to see how to lose your army fast watch this video.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I9QmIBV_bVY

column3: A fun little idle game that you can play a few times a day or even once.
One of the best games to make new enemies
Having a ton of fun with this so far. Only bug I have found is that the French don't surrender right away like real wars and can actually win.
I had high hopes for this
column4: but ended up being a let down. No PVP at launch or close to launch just means it will be dead forever now.
I really enjoyed their first game It came from space
column5: and ate our brains. So when I heard about this I had to take a look. Great story with some challenging gameplay. I have had to use brute force all the way to stealth to complete chapters. A bunch of different power ups you can buy from the shop to have different power moves. This is a must have for anyone that enjoys ARPGs. Fun achievements as well for my fellow achievement hunters.

column3: Such a great game for being EA. Takes me back to when I was a kid playing Mutant League Football and Hockey. This is such a good "spiritual predecessor". Definitely worth giving a try or even playing against friends online.  Here is a full game that shows the mayhem you can cause:   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hpjzU0GGMzA

column3: This used to be the milestone of DnD games. Everyone should take a look at it with this Enhanced Edition The price is worth it i gues.. ofc if you want it cheaper you can buy the standard diamond edition for probably less than half of it yet the enhanced has easier multiplayer
column5: compability fixes aswell as a more stable build. Not that many features got added
column6: its backwards compatible with old savegames and mods though so there is a??????ton of adventure modules for those that dont like the wonderful story of Neverwinter or already know it all  You cant play MP with the older versions due to version and added content So you either play Diamond edition or Enhanced. If all friends still play diamond it might be worth still playing diamond. New players will likely grab the enhanced edition over the diamond. The danger of splitting a community sadly exists with this - but once the enhanced edition is fully completed some ppl might mod Diamond to a way they can play together on mp as they were able to in the betabuilds  (and besides i think every loyal fan that played this for ages can drop 20$ once in a while on a remake like this)  There could be more features added.. yet they are still working on it  7/10 for the enhance (its okay but there still can be done a lot more and there will be a lot more) 10/10 for the game overall

I'm finally getting round to my review for Europa Universalis IV (EU4). Many may be suprised to see that I am not
column5: recommending this game. No doubt this review will receive criticism
column6: I can completely understand why. This game is dearly beloved by the Paradox community and is
column8: the most played and most popular game of the franchise. The brutal
column10: despite the things I am going to say in this review
column11: if you haven't purchased this game and are contemplating it
column12: you will probably enjoy it. The game does a lot right
column13: specifically the way that it juggles war and diplomacy
column14: and I would make the argument that EU4 is the epitome of grand strategy gaming. However
column15: this review is not a pandering of the mass opinion. Rather
column16: I am going to attempt to explain how I see the game in the hope that anyone like myself doesn't waste their money on something they will come to dislike.  EU4 does little wrong as a standalone game. It does what it says on the tin and it does it well. The issue comes with the wider picture. If this is your first venture into grand strategy games of any kind
column18: then purchase EU4. It is sweet and simple. To more experienced strategy gamers
column20: EU4 sees its first onion right here.  The game is too easy.  Not that its so easy that you could achieve world domination on your first playthrough
column22: what I mean by describing it as too easy is that the game is too simple - there isn't enough to do - and all of the difficulties are uncontrollable random events. Other games - its strategy brethen in particular - don't have this issue. Whilst random events do occasionally come in to shake things up
column23: the emphasis is on the strategy
column24: the methods you employ to improve your scenario and the risk factors involved in making these decisions. Other strategy games tend to work like an echo chamber. Crusader Kings 2 (full review on my profile)
column26: is a perfect example of this. When a random event occurs that hinders you - or when you employ a risky strategy that fails - you could lose everything. Your kingdom could collapse
column27: you could go into serious debt and you might even be killed
column28: whittling your dynasty down to the imbecilic cousins you've spent years trying to hide. However
column29: and this is where the magic is
column30: the game isn't over. In CK2 you are perfectly capable - and I know because i've done it - of taking this depleted position and slowly and methodically scheming your way to the top
column32: murder and sex. By placing so much emphasis on the personal motives and intrigue
column33: CK2 does as good a job as The Godfather or House of Cards. CK2 encourages you to fail and rewards you when you do. Success in Crusader Kings 2 makes the game harder - with far more internal threats - whilst failure motivates you to regain everything you've lost. Europa Universalis simply can't do this. It's so black and white. When you fail
column35: it's game over and when you succeed you are unstoppable. This isn't challenging and it isn't fun. It's simply a poorly made difficulty slider. The fact that EU4 lacks the political intrigue and threats of other strategy games means that its entire focus is on the military. It's a game about blobbing and colouring the map. There's nothing wrong with this
column36: but it makes it easy and simple. the fact that it is entirely reliant on dice roll - quite literally - with two armies clashing and the winner being decided by randomly generated numeric values
column37: means that it isn't a strategy game. It's gambling.  Strategy
column39: is the art of creatively overcoming certain circumstances. When you have a game that presents either one nation being vastly superior to another
column41: when the two are on equal footing the victor being decided by the roll of a dice
column42: there is no strategy involved. It is luck and chance
column43: and this makes Europea Universalis IV simple and easy.  Playing as a major nation
column46: makes it impossible to genuinely be strategically outmanouvred. You will almost always have the larger army
column48: the better technology. You are fighting a downhill battle and the only things that can really defeat you are things out of your control - random events or coalitions. It's like a train without brakes - it ploughs through almost everything and the only thing to challenge it is when something else comes along and forces it off the tracks. When did this become strategy?  Truly
column49: this game is akin to a Total War campaign where you only auto-resolve battles.  The natural opposition to what i'm saying is that you should play a more difficult nation - an OPM or technologically inferior state - however
column50: even then it's not strategic. You only have one way to go: up. It's a slow grind
column52: and you will often fail. However

column3: The Witcher 3 has many great points and features

column5: from the side characters); the world feels real and you are given a wide variety of choices in regards to how to play the game
column6: based on decisions in dialogue.  Easily the most impressive thing about the game is it's ability to use narrative and dialogue to create an immersive experience
column7: bringing the player into the world and allowing you to appreciate the story.  However
column8: the devs missed one thing. They forgot to make the game fun.  That's not to say it's terrible
column9: unlike its predecessor (The Witcher 2) I was able to complete this game. The latter felt like running a marathon with no legs when I tried to play
column10: because it was so bad.  Now
column11: I can already hear the fanboys screaming
column14: you're too simple to appreciate a story well told through dialogue and just want action sequences". My reply: that couldn't be further from the truth. I love stories told through well presented dialogue. Reservoir Dogs is one of my all time favourite films
column15: as is Goodfellas. I love TV shows such as House of Cards or even HBO's Rome. The Witcher 3 does have nice dialogue
column16: it's just not a well made game.  It can't decide whether it wants to be a film or a game. Other triple A games such as Skyrim have made their mind
column17: most (including Skyrim) abandon a well made story for fun and free gameplay. The Witcher wants to do that
column18: but it's narrative focus makes it linear and chokes the player. You are given near to no freedom and the minor choices you make in dialogue make little to no difference on the gameplay
column19: only impacting things such as character relations and the ending.  And even the story telling isn't good enough
column20: despite its heavy focus. The protagonist

column32: linear and boring pair in order to fit into the plot and to force the story on. The characters are a blank canvass
column33: to allow the dialogue to shape the story. The problem is

column38: alter their education and even their appearance (the appearance of the protagonists in The Witcher 3 further adds to their bland nature
column40: grey hair reflecting their dull personality). It is a game that then throws you into the world and you are NOT limited by a linear story or a bland
column41: pre-determined character. It is a true RPG. Each action
column43: has permanent actions on the world you are in and the AI around you (all of whom are intelligent and fighting for their own ambitions
column44: dreams and desires instead of simply being there to prop up the main character's story). I believe The Witcher 3 attempts to be like Crusader Kings 2
column45: but fails miserably.  The supporting performances in TW3 are exotic and exciting - with Charles Dance even making a wonderful appearance - but these supporting characters are only given a snippet of on-screen time. Their well-written
column46: acted and developed characters are whisked away with a fast-paced plot taking place in a world that is too big and too ambitious for this game.  In addition to a boring
column47: choking and linear plot with dull main characters and not enough appearances of the side characters
column48: the game is too big. The map is so large that you don't spend enough time in any one particular locations and don't get to appreciate it. The side quests are repetitive
column49: boring and take up far too much time. Why
column50: if Geralt is so desperate to find someone
column51: would he waste his time completing meaningless quests for side characters he's only just met?  They fall into the same pattern of: use your Witcher senses to explore or find an item. Follow an NPC. Fight a boss battle. Watch a cut scene. Rinse

column4: but one that suffers from many of the pitfalls of today's gaming mentality. The game is full of cute additions that quite quickly become incredibly annoying. The constant talking heads (some of which can be disabled in the expansion apparently)

column7: but you'd think they'd make "fluff" less aggrivating. There are other "features" that I found offputting
column9: or hindered my enjoyment. The entire "Ant Farm" base being a good example of something that serves absolutely no function.  Gameplay is simplified from the original X-Com quite a bit
column10: sometimes with artificial limitations that don't make sense when looked at critically. My honest opinion about the game was that the AI cheated
column11: or the game had no idea how to computate odds for various actions. Which is odd
column12: given that the original X-Com; a very difficult game never felt like it cheated. It comes down to the difference in presentation: One soldier in X-Com means nothing. In Enemy Unknown it means everything. That one soldier can be the difference between failure and loss; making the AI "cheating" or being "cheap" incredibly frustrating.  Also has to be mentioned that 2K promised mod support prior to release
column13: but then changed their tune once the game came out
column15: which nukes mod support unless you run it offline or without autoupdate. Not a cool move. There's also the bugs

column7: vicious war in Ireland put paid to any chance of a Catholic Stuart restoration. Nonetheless

column3: The definitive Fire Pro game. But despite that as of (June 2018) the game still has massive flaws with its online functions and workshop support. Specifically you still get desyncs in multiplayer against other people which is unacceptable and the workshop is completely broken in it's implementation. Good luck if you want to delete a guy you've downloaded. Not only do you have to unsubscribe from the mod in Steam but then you have to go into Fire Pro and manually delete the wrestler in question. The game doesn't list edits in any alphabetical listing
column4: nor does it make this a speedy process. If you have 800 edits you've downloaded you're in for a very "fun" time.  There's also the issue of not delivering promised DLC content when they were supposed to. No Management of Rings mode despite being slated to be released in January 2018. Hopefully the Steam verison is updated when the PS4 copy is released later this year.

column3: A solid game that doesn't really live up to its Fallout lineage. They spent far too much effort on the Settlement parts of the game to the detriment of everything else. The settlement/building not only doesn't fit the Fallout universe
column4: it completely breaks immersion when you can instantly take apart a car that's been sitting in the wasteland for the last two hundred years.   FO4 is still a fun game if you're just looking for adventure and exploration. But if you're looking for something with more substance then that I'd steer clear.

column3: Fallen Enchantress Legendary Heroes is one of the most criminally underlooked 4X strategy games out there. It doesn't help that Stardock itself doesn't understand the franchise and radically changed the game's structure with the inferior Sorcerer King games.  What sets FE:LH apart:  - A unique world setting. The gameworld is ruined at game start. All civilization has been destroyed by the Cataclysm and you are tasked with rebuilding. Most of the world is uninhabitable with only select places on the map being suited for colonization and wild enemies roam the map. You'll encounter quests and events from those surviving and those regarding the history of the world and its twisted creatures where even living gods were perverted.  - Many victory conditions including your usual 4X conditions such as conquering
column4: but also an ascension to god-hood and a master quest to redeem the world itself.  - Each faction in the game can be used by different leaders and each faction plays differently allowing for quite a bit of replayability and roleplaying.  - Strong creation tools and modding allowing you to create or change the game significantly. The modding scene has dried up but many mods are still compatible.  Negatives:  - DLC is pretty lackluster with Stardock clearly trying to mine the fans of the game for more money. Among the more damning is The Dead DLC where the AI is completely inept at playing with the new faction's unique mechanics.  - Tactical combat isn't the strongest but functional. It's not anywhere near the complexity of something like Age of Wonders.  - Stardock in general. The game still has issues that they never fixed or modified and it's become clear over time that Stardock has abandoned what made this game good in order to repackage and appeal to new customers with the more limited "streamlined" Sorcerer King games.  While not a perfect game
column5: Fallen Enchantress Legendary Heroes is a great 4X game taking place in a unique world. I highly recommend any serious TBS fans give the game a look.

Just awesome.  Brought my Laptop to a friend. Then I ripped his heart out and danced around with a blade in his head.  11/10 would recommend.
Very deep and competitive PvP Brawler/FPS.  Due to its innovative gameplay
column4: you can't compare it to classical genres.  All the different classes that can be also customized offer also a very strategic experience with lots of complex and possible combinations of teams and the classes themself.   Beginners might find it difficult to keep up to all the task one has to fulfill in order to play a good round but the game is worth every second of playing :)

column3: I can only agree with the review that states how misleading the User reviews are on this DLC. A free patch (2.5) actually implemented the new Infamy mechanic with the new coalitions aswell as the new retreating-status of armies.  Of course it's once again 15¢ã for something that possibly should be free like the last patch or not being sold for more than 5¢ã
column4: but this is another story.  About this DLC
column6: i really like how the council got emphasized in importance. Also the new Opinion scale they patched in seems to be made for this DLC as it balances the newly added focus you've got to keep on your vassals.  PS: Luckily enough I haven't encountered any muslim coalitions lead by the pope e.g. yet
column7: but I hope Paradox will fix these historical issues with coalitions being also based on an opinion modifier etc. (Only my saves seem to have been harmed a little^^)  PSS: I enjoy every additional DLC for the Paradox Grand Strategy games as much as any other addict. And in my opinion its okay-ish that they continue adding content if they made prices more fair maybe. Also I'd rather have this game getting more and more depth and content than a new CK3 that starts from Vanilla with 8325760 DLCs to come. *sigh*

column3: Good content and another must have for a Paradox addict like me. ?(?Òæ??) But at what cost?   Please introduce season passes or other ways to cope with that DLC flood.

column3: *capitalist fat dude in top hat*  and yep
column4: magadan (was) definitely the richest place in USSR and whole world as well  the developer doesn't seem to be slacking and quality of life improvements are there
column5: even mod tools too it seems  surely this is rather serious simulation compared to maybe any i seen at all - and it's quite fun in that  numerous AIs compete quite well and iirc it's not easy to wrestle much of market from them; the only downside was maybe either poor longterm planning or maybe not strong enough problem fixing when scit happens like lengthy world wars  and yet i suppose it's pretty realistic that they succumb to ruined business - yet game seems to allow survival in some of the direst conditions with good enough plans  currently (1.23) game map is kind of compressed with smaller and weird younger cities cut - but old one (1.21 or even older) is still there to play with 264 cities including even north korea
column7: kyrgyzstan. etc.  1 massive problem might persist however: while game allows like 1440 turns in timeframe of 1900-2020 - it seems savegames awfully bloat (database issue) even in like ~30-35 years which overall makes it unplayable in super long timeframes (this was in 1.21 older experience; now i have no idea - there is a new option to autopurge reports older than 5 years but not sure if it works well yet)  previously as well there was bit too much clumsiness and excessive management (or more like redundant actions
column8: templates) required - now it's on path to eradication  all in all it's definitely interesting game
column9: simulation and worth a buy now - i'd say plenty of different styles and replayability too

column9: which is great addition i think; + variability to silk road trade;  If you wonder what are the added casus bellis - it seems they are levy/manpower tributary wars + religious kingdom sized liberation(then tributary) in limited cases + similar large realm great conquest + limited force vassalize + bunch of ducal conquest/border dispute  That means you generally can start wars at will(with neighbors) with some drawbacks like poor opinion about that + have some excuse to simpler/conquering within a duchy where you own at least something (however CBs as well are kind of costly in one way or another) - should be a welcome addition to a warmonger  EDIT: also my quite old playthrough started a long while ago at earliest playable date(charlemagne) now only in like 12th century still(near world conquest roman empire) - was started in possibly even 2.5 patch(or 2.4

column3: It's good for what it is! I prefer Victoria 2 over this (and all other Pdx' titles) and can also see why people think this game stands no chance against EU4.  However
column4: March of the Eagles focuses on a rather short time period around the Battle of Waterloo 1815.  So don't expect too much!  So what is this game?  Maybe it doesn't convince as much in terms of Grand Strategy as other Paradox titles
column5: but it has a good potential and the military aspect is well done.  So the huge contra is that PDS simply abandoned this game and left it with all the flaws :-(

I finally put a lot of hours into CAU last night
column4: going through all 12 of the new police missions
column6: doing several crate delivery missions (as a bad guy) and joining in several police chases (to stop the bad guy). I also levelled up to 60 in the process.  My opinion is that the new chases are great fun. They add a new dimension to the gameplay
column7: which frankly has become a little stale after 500+ hours in the game. The police chases freshen it up a lot. It's much more exciting to be chased by real players than the AI police
column8: while chasing down and arresting real players is extremely satisfying.  However
column9: the DLC is very poor value for money
column10: unless you don't own Wild Run
column11: in which case it's great value for money because you get both. If you've already purchased Wild Run
column12: then it's a bit of a rip off. They really should have sold it at a discount for Wild Run owners.  The good news: you don't have to own CAU to be a criminal and do the crate delivery missions
column13: so everybody gets half of the new content for free!  The bad news: there are only 12 new missions and the story is pretty much non-existent. Unlike the original story missions there are no cut-scenes for most of them
column14: so we don't even get to see the bad guy we're after. We're just chasing a name. The missions don't take long to complete
column15: I did them all in an hour or so
column16: and I got no sense of satisfaction or connection to the so called story. I expected a lot more
column17: like the original story that was much more engaging.  Having said that
column18: the new missions are a lot of fun and I spent a lot of time repeating many of them
column19: trying to score platinum in each. That's a very quick way to level up your police cars. Due to the nature of the chases
column20: they can be different each time. In fact
column21: doing badly is more fun than catching them quickly because you get a longer chase to enjoy.  The real fun though
column22: is chasing (or being chased by) real players rather than the idiot AI who are usually quite easy to beat (except on the harder missions). And of course
column23: there are a few new cars available and being a cop in supercar is really cool.  In summary: It's a lot of fun and I'm really enjoying it
column24: but it's very poor value for money if you already own Wild Run. If you love this game
column27: why not? If you don't have Wild Run
column28: it's very good value. If you're on the fence

column3: Lux Delux is a Risk style game
column4: similar in many ways to the original but with several extra features. Although the game mechanics are very simple
column5: the strategy is often quite challenging.   https://youtu.be/DTupYOTo90Q  Probably the most outstanding feature of this game is that there are over 900 maps available
column6: providing endless variety in the gameplay. Most of these are created by users so the quality varies widely
column7: but there are more than enough good maps to keep you occupied.   https://youtu.be/vkfetLs8z0g  Another great feature is the AI
column8: which is really well programmed. There's around a dozen bots of different difficulty levels
column9: each of which has a different playstyle. The hard bots are REALLY tough to beat! Additionally there's multiplayer so there's plenty of humans to go up against.  Graphics are pretty basic
column10: but they're perfectly functional for this kind of game. Many of the maps are really well designed.  It's a fairly quick game to play
column11: although it can take longer on some bigger maps or against tougher opponents
column12: so it's great for when you have 10 or 20 minutes to spare.  I recommend this for anyone who craves a quick strategy fix but doesn't have enough time for a full game of Civ 5 or Hearts of Iron 3!
