The Crew is a multiplayer always-online arcade-racer set in a huge open world which is a condensed version of the United States. It was designed by many of the same people who created Test Drive Unlimited
column4: so it can effectively be thought of as TDU 3. It contains many of the same features
column5: but not all (no houses or shops).   http://youtu.be/CBYh4vPmH2k  I think many people are unfairly critical of this game
column6: and are failing to appreciate the best feature
column7: the huge open world. In reality
column8: the world area is only around 5000 sq km (about a quarter of the size of Wales)
column9: yet that's still a huge size for a game world
column10: possibly the second largest open world racing game (Fuel is over twice as big). Road wise
column13: 10 times as much as in the first TDU game
column14: so that will take a long time to explore properly. But it's not just the size of the world that's impressive
column15: it's the attention to detail and the huge number of landmarks. It's extremely well designed.  The USA is not only condensed
column17: some areas are much larger than others. This is necessary since if everything was to scale
column18: every city would be a tiny village. Instead
column19: the biggest cities are made much larger
column20: as well as features like the Grand Canyon
column21: while less interesting areas are shrunk in size. The result is greatly distorted
column22: but it feels really good to drive around
column23: and I believe it does a good job of representing the "highlights" of the USA in a way which suits a computer game very well.   https://youtu.be/vNx4FtHofwU  Many people have complained about the horrible car physics. I was a bit shocked at this too in the beginning
column24: but it turns out that the early cars handle badly by design
column25: and get much better as you upgrade them with parts. The few cars I've tried from the DLCs handle much better. It also takes a little while to tweak your wheel or controller settings to get it to feel good
column26: but it's worth the effort.   http://youtu.be/KksGtk6F-i8  Apparently rubber banding is also a problem in the game
column27: although I did read someone say it's been fixed. I've noticed it a few times with police chases
column28: but it doesn't seem to be much of a problem to me. Speaking of police chases
column29: I find them to be a lot of fun
column30: while others seem to hate them. Similarly
column31: the raid challenges can be quite frustrating
column32: but are also fun to me. Depends on your point of view I suppose.  The GPS tends to provide the shortest route between two points
column33: which is often not the best way to get to where you want quickly (taking you through backstreets instead of sticking to main roads)
column35: SatNav does that in real life too! Just think of it as a guide that you don't have to stick to. Learning the main roads and using your "local knowledge" instead can save time! Also it tends to suggest offroad shortcuts
column36: which can be annoying if you want to stick to roads
column38: it gives you a route through difficult scenery which you might otherwise get stuck in.  One annoying thing I have noticed is graphical glitches during the cut scene intros to most missions. Don't know what's causing this
column39: but it's only a minor irritation
column40: it doesn't happen when I'm driving.  Another slight peeve is that much of the terrain is too destructible
column41: you can drive straight through lamp posts and other features as if they weren't even there
column42: yet some are rock solid. It's sometimes hard to know which is which. Okay
column43: so it's just an arcade game so you could say it's excusable
column44: but it does lead to bad driving habits
column45: driving through obstacles that you'd normally avoid. In fact
column46: to win certain missions it's often a good idea to crash through things.   https://youtu.be/blIdOUmGMh8  Same goes for crashing into other cars
column47: often (not always) this has little or no effect
column48: barely slowing you down in most instances. Again
column49: I don't like this because it encourages bad driving habits
column50: not caring about hitting other cars when normally you should try to avoid them at all costs. But again
column52: so I can live with it.  Sure
column53: there are a few faults with this game
column54: but most of them hardly matter to me. The game world is so large
column55: with so many places to go
column56: so many things to see (there's educational info on historical landmarks) and so many cars to drive (not a huge selection
column57: but there are many variants of each
column58: and who needs hundreds of cars anyway?) that I'm having too much fun cruising and exploring to take much notice of the faults. I think if people focused less on the faults and concentrated more on the fun aspects of the game
column59: they'd enjoy it a lot more.  For me the FreeDrive mode is the real game
column60: going on road trips solo or with friends. I dont' really care about the missions and the story that much (although they do add a nice bit of character to the game)
column61: I just want to explore America!  Having said that
column62: the game gets more interesting the deeper you get into it. As you level up you unlock factions and faction missions
column63: and that adds a lot more fun to the game
column64: not to mention money! Some say that money is hard to come by and there's a lot of grinding
column66: money is easy to make. It's not a "pay to win" game
column67: you can pay if you're lazy
column68: but you can make it easily enough by simply playing the game.  I'm really enjoying The Crew and I highly recommend it to positive gamers who enjoy exploring a huge open world
column69: who don't mind the arcadey gameplay and can live with a few faults. Be sure to get the Gold Edition or buy the Season Pass to get a bunch of good cars that unlock fairly early in the game
column70: to give you a decent variety of cars to go free roaming in
column71: otherwise you'll be stuck with the early cars for a while.  Negative focused nit-pickers need not apply!

column3: RaceRoom is an excellent sim racer made by the same people behind Simbin
column4: makers of Race 07 and other great sims. It's worthy of serious consideration by everyone who loves sim racing. Don't be fooled by the many bad reviews
column5: there's a good reason for them
column6: which I'll explain later. There's also more good news later.   https://youtu.be/itBXrA2QEEM   http://youtu.be/I7URfx-CpwE  Raceroom offers a large collection of cars (75 in total) and tracks (25 in total
column7: many of which have several different layouts) and 3 competitions (2 DTM and ADAC) which are called "Experiences". These Experiences give you full seasons with teams and drivers. In short
column8: there's a lot of variety in this game.  I haven't put many hours into this game yet
column9: but so far I've found the racing "experience" to be extremely good. Physics are very realistic and the AI seems pretty good too. One very nice feature is the ARI (Adapative Racing Intelligence) which adjusts the difficulty level automatically to match your skill and experience. At first I wasn't impressed with this since the AI drivers were driving too slowly
column10: but apparently the difficulty level starts low and increases over time. After a few races the AI had adapted to my level and started to provide some decent competition without being overly difficult to beat.  There are three racing modes; Novice
column11: Amateur and Get Real. Novice is a bit of a joke since it actually brakes for you as you approach the corners. Amateur has realistic physics
column13: ABS and zero damage. Get Real turns the driving aids off (but damage is still optional). It's a pity I couldn't configure all these things separately
column14: I'd like to have driven on Amateur level but with damage turned on for example.  Now the bad news...  Many people have criticised this game for being free to play but with very little content. That's true
column15: but what do you expect for free? You get 5 different cars and 3 tracks (each with several variations)
column16: more than enough to evaluate the quality of the game and give you some great racing fun for no more than the price of the download.  Think of it this way
column17: the "free to play" game is just a demo
column18: the REAL game is in the addon packs. Three of the DLCs currently available on Steam are "Experiences" - full seasons with tracks and cars - DTM 2013 and 2014
column19: ADAC 2014. It actually makes more sense to buy these as DLCs rather than buying a whole new game every year
column20: as with the F1 games. The fourth DLC is just a car pack
column21: not an "Experience".  Here's where the problems begin...  The three Experience DLCs contain a lot of duplicate content. They mostly use the same tracks and some of the same cars. For example
column22: the two DTM packs only have 1 track and 1 car different. This makes buying all the DLCs a waste of money
column23: because you're paying for mostly the same content that you've already bought.  To confuse matters even more
column24: there are many more packs you can buy that aren't available as Steam DLCs
column25: as well as individual cars and tracks
column26: some of which are not available in any packs. You can buy them in-game or from their website. These are bought using the in-game currency of vRP points
column27: so you can't see what they cost in real money. However
column28: if you add the items to your cart you can see the cost.  I created a spreadsheet to show what's available in each pack
column29: which you may find helpful;   http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=445609150  Whoever came up with this ridiculous marketing/sales model should be fired. It confuses buyers and can result in wasted money buying duplicate content. Judging by the number of negative reviews
column31: which is a pity. I hope they don't go bankrupt again because of this!  Fortunately
column32: there is some good news...  While experimenting with adding various packs to the cart on their website
column33: I discovered that they DON'T CHARGE FOR DUPLICATE CONTENT! They know what cars and tracks you own
column34: so you don't pay extra for what you already have. So if you already own DTM 2013
column35: DTM 2014 will be cheaper as a result. I wanted to buy all the tracks but was loathe to buy the European Track Pack for just one extra track
column36: but when I added it to my cart
column37: it cost less than a pound extra
column38: less than half the price of buying that track individually!  So
column39: it's okay to buy ONE Experience pack from Steam
column40: but if you want any more
column41: buy them from their site instead. Also
column43: you won't be charged for it.  Even more good news
column44: the more packs you buy at one time
column45: the cheaper they get. There's a cumulative discount
column46: so if you're going to buy any packs
column47: buy as many as you can afford to save more money. I bought 7 items and got a 16% discount. If you buy all the packs I think you get a discount of around 30%  To give you an idea of cost
column48: I spent less than ?30 to get all the tracks and about a third of the cars. I could have gotten all of the tracks cheaper than that
column49: but I wanted some extra cars as well. Two tracks are not contained in any pack. Buying all the packs would cost around ?70 I think
column50: but unless you're a collector who has to have everything
column51: it doesn't need to cost that much.  CONCLUSION: I highly recommend this game to all sim racers. Those who prefer casual or arcade racing should probably avoid this game (but by all means try the "demo" first). The DLCs
column52: packs and points method of selling this game is overly complex and confusing
column53: but if you like this game
column54: don't be put off by that
column56: and it's much cheaper to buy the extras direct from the game or their website

column3: In this game you play as the goddess Athena
column4: who's job it is to guide Odysseus' boats to safety. You do this by altering the wind strength
column5: which always blows toward their destination
column6: and by dragging your mouse through the sea to create currents.  This sounds simple enough
column7: but you also have to prevent the ships from hitting rocks and sand bars
column8: and avoiding other dangers like a cyclops throwing rocks at them (you can catch the rocks by clicking on them with the mouse). Additionally you need to direct the boats to statues to unlock gates and there are also bonuses to pick up along the way. Naturally it gets harder as you progress
column9: with newer dangers and more difficult maps to negotiate.  Although the graphics are pleasing
column10: the resolution is only 640x480. You have a choice of full screen or windowed.  To be honest
column11: it's not my type of game and it didn't hold my interest for very long
column12: but it's by no means a bad game. It wouldn't appeal to everyone
column13: but it's fairly challenging and I'm sure some gamers would enjoy it.  Conclusion: a decent casual game ideal for a quick play when you don't have much time to spare.

column3: Flockers is an action puzzle game in much the same style as Lemmings
column6: so you know the pedigree is good.   https://youtu.be/YQXgOCYvZFg  For those who don't remember the classic Lemmings
column7: it was a game in which a number of "lemmings" (which looked more like human workers to me) were released and would walk through the landscape
column8: following each other like the archetypal lemmings
column9: blindly walking off cliffs to their death. Your job as the player was to guide the lemmings by giving specific instructions to them
column10: for example to build bridges or dig into the landscape
column11: in order to guide as many of them to safety as possible.  Flockers uses essentially the same concept
column12: but with sheep instead of lemmings. Appropriately so
column13: since sheep also have the habit of following one another. This time around
column15: you have to help them navigate through extremely dangerous factory complexes
column19: often with gory results as your mindless sheep stroll blindly into them.  Each level is a puzzle. They're large
column20: and get progressively more complicated as you progress through them. You can zoom in and out to get a better view of the puzzle you have to solve. Sheep may wander off in different directions
column21: you may meet more sheep along the way
column22: transporters teleport sheep to different locations and it can sometimes be a bit confusing to understand what's going on the first time you try a new level.  As you go through each level
column23: sheep step on buttons which activate machinery
column25: sometimes in a very bad way
column26: so you have to be very careful what you let them step on. They also encounter crates
column27: which when opened give you new abilities that you can assign to your your sheep. It may take a few attempts to figure out how to get through a level.  While you often need to get only one sheep to safety (in the early levels at least)
column28: getting more will score you more points
column29: as will doing it in a faster time. You also get a bonus for using fewer abilities. You can retry levels to get a better score
column30: and you can compare your score to your friends.  The levels are very detailed
column32: which can make it tricky to figure out how to solve them. But maybe that's the point
column33: distracting you with unimportant details. Fortunately
column35: you can pause it at any time
column36: giving you the opportunity to study the puzzle at your leisure. You still have to solve it in real time though
column37: giving commands to your sheep as they move. Pressing the right mouse button gives you a bigger "brush"
column38: enabling you to give commands to multiple sheep at the same time.  The graphics are very good
column39: and very gory as sheep get smashed and sawed
column42: which is rather amusing if you find that sort of thing funny. For this reason the game has an age rating. But if you don't like that sort of thing
column43: you can simply turn off the gore in the video options.  I haven't played this game for very long yet
column44: but my first impressions are very good. I'm finding it both challenging and amusing
column45: an enjoyable casual way to pass the time. The price is very reasonable and it's on sale at the moment
column46: so this is a great time to grab it if you're interested.

column3: Drizzlepath: Genie is a walking simulator that takes you on a journey through beautiful scenery. The rain soaked atmosphere is very relaxing. It's not as dark as Dear Esther. The colours are quite muted
column4: but that's appropriate for an overcast day. The landscape contains various locations and objects of interest and it's worth looking around to find things you might otherwise miss.  Occasional voice narration enhances the experience. It's extremely poetic and descriptive
column5: painting pictures in words to further enhance the visuals. There's also relaxing music providing a soundtrack to your journey. It's pleasant enough to listen to but can get repetitive at times. I usually turn music off once that happens (which it does with all games)
column6: and often play without music or replace it with music of my own choice. It would be nice to have that option added. It's enjoyable enough just listening to the rain IMO.  There are many excellent opportunities for screenshots in this game
column7: which can extend the gameplay time considerably. There's a control to zoom out to give a wider angle of view and another to crouch
column8: which can provide you with a different viewpoint. You can even change to a grainy
column9: monochrome view which gives a completely different look to the game
column10: and is good for "arty" screenshots.  In spite of the overcast sky
column11: sunlight does stream through gaps in the clouds. Unusually it shines from multiple directions. Perhaps this planet orbits multiple suns? This sunlight causes purple lens flare
column13: but sometimes I felt there was a bit too much of it and I wished I could turn it off. UPDATE: If you set filter effects to medium or low the lens flare will be disabled.  It may be worth noting that I have not experienced any of the micro-stutters than mrorange mentioned in his review.  I don't understand what everything means in this game because I haven't completed it yet. In fact
column14: I've only been exploring the green path so far (there are two different paths through the game)
column15: but after three hours I think I've experienced enough to write this review. I'll update it once I've played more. Unfortunately I suffer from motion sickness in first person games so I can't play them for too long without feeling ill. I also take loads of screenshots so it'll take me a lot longer to complete than if I simply walked through it all without stopping.  Overall this is a very pleasant visual and aural experience (rather than a game) which I recommend to anyone who enjoys simply walking around and looking at beautiful scenery. It's a treat to the senses and is ideal for relaxation when you feel like taking a break from more demanding games.  Disclaimer: a key was provided by the developer in return for an unbiased review
column16: which is the only kind of review I'm willing to write.

column3: Pro: - interesting setting - low learning curve - very diverse building blocks - multiple races and the racism that naturally occurs between races (no sugar coating of reality) - engaging fasttravel system
column4: that doesn't unnecessarily shrink the world - varied combat weapons and abilities  Con: - trivial difficulty
column6: easy self-healing - extremely quick progression - no need to build - no nostaliga moments
column7: as you simply switch planets instead of conquering a world - poor performance despite bing a pixel art game - slow development
column8: Early Access for the ages - short sense of exploration
column9: because progress is quick you opt into landing
column11: mining -> next tier -> repeat - food/buffs are meaningless - unprecise movement - early movement upgrades - crafting > finding / unlocking  The first time I got Starbound I managed to "finish" the game so quickly that it didn't last an saturday afternoon. Expected from early access. Now
column13: it doesn't seem to have changed much other than it takes slightly longer
column14: because now there are missions between the tiers. They aren't difficult nor are they that interesting. The first game of this sandbox type I played was Terraria and I played that in it's early stages too. The difficulty was higher but not torturing but more importantly
column15: you felt the need to connect with your world. If you went to far in one direction or too deep you ended up fighting monsters outside of your current combat strengh. In Starbound the transition from a weak explorer to a stronger one is very clearly cut. It's switching the planet you're exploring. And it's not like you can go to higher tiers earlier to seek out a challenge because you'll end up dealing with constant health loss due to artificially giving the next tier of planet something you later deal with passively by progression. Starbound had the need to stay warm in early stages and it slowed you down. Apparently enough people complained for this to be removed. But that's exactly what made Terraria great and Starbound badly designed now: You explore too quickly. In Terraria you had little means of moving around until you were well into higher tiers. In Starbound you get doublejump
column16: anti-fall damage and grapple hooks (good idea but it speeds up everything) and then you blast your way through worlds. No need to build anything either. You put the crafting stations on your ship and that's that. Either you love spending time on housing and then do it or you completely skip it. That might sound like a nice thing. Do what you want and skip everything else. But one of the most important parts of a task is to have a purpose. Good design creats the need  and  desire to do something
column17: which Starbound fails to do. If you enjoy housing building there are better ways to do it. If you enjoy exploring there are better ways to do it. If you enjoy combat there are a lot better ways to do it.  Starbound had potential and probably still has. But it doesn't seem like the developer is moving in a direction which attacks there points. The ease of access to everything doesn't make for a good game. It makes for a good level editor but that's not what Starbound wants to be or would perform well at either.

column4: despite not liking RTS otherwise.  - The learning curve.. ..doesn't seem too steep and the units are pretty straight forward and don't need brutal micromanagement because they don't have special skills to activate. On top of that you get some pretty  awesome and powerful tools  to ease the micromanagement of your armies like patrol a route or area and other things like "reclaim area" which saves up a lot of thinking and micromanaging when you start to scale your war efforts up to hundreds of units (each commandable on it's own).  - The game play is.. ..quite well already and doesn't feel as incomplete as other Early Access games. Definitly worth playing now
column5: despite minor hickups and laggs when things get hot (though this might be more a problem of m 4 year old gaming notebook). The fact that you're fighting on multiple maps (planets) makes it so much more engaging than having a fixed strategy for a certain map and executing it quicker and better than the other player means winning the game.  - Multi-Team and dynamic-Teams.. ..really is something I missed in the last years (though I didn't try that many RTS). The last RTS I remember having dynamic alliances was C&C Red Alert (1). It adds so much to the game when you can actively react to the game flow other than building units. It means you interact with the player and not only the game. And of course
column6: having multiple planets goes so well with having multiple teams. I've watched massive games with 25 people fighting in teams of 5 over one planet and I've watched a game on youtube where they played 5v10v10 where they ended the game with a massive annihilation of the primary planet when a team gained control of the two moons. Really intensifies the gameplay beyond simple warfare.  - Galactic War.. ..is the sort-of singleplayer campain where I'm currently learning to play different strategies. You start out only having access to the vehicle factory (first commander you have) and within one war (campain) you add new abilities by defeating foes on planet systems. I do hope they add coop galactic war and extend it (add a new game mode) which is like Tactical Commander/Shatterd Galaxies and Planet Side 2 where you take over Systems as part of a greater group of players. I do believe that's being planned but I don't know for sure.  - Ongoing development.. ..I don't usually count this as a bonus point because it usually also means the current game feels incomplete
column8: Planetary Annihilation is already stable and complex enough to enjoy for hours on end. At this point
column9: having new stuff flowing in just adds to the fun.  - System Editor.. ..create your own systems and planet designs to fit special multiplayer matches. What's not to love about that?   All in all I'm glad I picked up during summer sale and excited to have an RTS for once that doesn't annoy me.

column3: Governor of Poker 2 is an enjoyable poker game set in the Wild West
column4: that offers more than just poker. There's a long campaign where you travel to different cities
column6: encounter a variety of different opponents (including notorious ones)
column9: you get to buy new hats!   https://youtu.be/obuXfORI8v0  A big feature of real poker is the tells on your opponents faces
column10: but in this game you don't see faces
column11: just hats! In spite of this
column12: the game does a pretty good job of giving different personalities to the characters through their voices and actions
column13: and there are tells in the form of comments they make and other information
column14: such as getting steamy when they lose.  A big part of the game is travelling to different cities and buying buildings
column15: which provide you with passive income. At first you can only make money from playing poker
column16: but once you own a reasonable number of buildings you have a steady income trickling in. The idea is to build up your reputation and take over different cities. You can borrow money from the bank if necessary
column17: or sell buildings if you have any
column19: you can buy new hats. New hats impart some personality to the players and allow you to enter new tournaments.  The gameplay is fairly fast paced
column20: it's an ideal game for a quick poker fix
column21: but I'm not sure whether the cards played are truly random and whether the AI cheats or not. Some reviews claim that it does. I'm not experienced at poker so I can't really tell
column22: but as a casual player the gameplay seems decent to me
column23: even though I find it pretty hard to win
column24: even on the standard level. The Telltale poker games are a lot more fun if you want personality and banter
column25: but for a simple poker fix
column26: this does the job and is better than other poker games I've tried. There's no multiplayer
column27: so look elsewhere if that's what you want
column28: but it provides a good single player experience  The graphics are fairly basic
column30: but they're functional and pleasant to look at. There are free versions of this you can play on the internet but this version
column32: provides more depth.  Overall I'd recommend this game for casual players
column33: especially because of the extra interest that the campaign provides. Serious poker players may want to look elsewhere though.

column3: If you enjoyed the free TrackMania Nations you'll enjoy this one too. Basically it's just an update with better performance (for me at least) and graphics and no annyoing online limitations of the freeware version of TM Nations. If you already have a limitation free TM Nations you don't really need to upgrade unless you want to be at the heartbeat of the community. I'm sure it's still pretty active on the predecessor though. You do get to use steam workshop though which makes handling maps more comfortable.  For anyone completely new to TrackMania
column4: be sure to invest in a controller with a very fine joystick (Xbone One seems fit). My old Logitech controller isn't fit for the fine adjustments because the stick needs too much force to move.

column3: As far as 2D exploration games with building and mining goes
column4: Terraria is the first that I'd recommend to anyone. It's quite complex without being too complex for first time sandbox players and it evolved to delivering hours of gameplay even if you just rush to kill and explore everything there is in a single "playthrough".  Pros: - Finished - Much content - well balanced - dedicated servers - etc.  Cons: - Needs portforwarding to host servers which can be confusing for some - once you know the ins and outs of the game the next time you pick it up you'll rush through it

column3: I highly recommend this game to anyone who likes playing quick

Pros: - local/online multiplayer (no need to have 4 PCs running just because one person isn't around) - community involvement (I think so) - easy to learn with complexity to master (dodging grapples
column5: setting up grapple traps) - leveleditor - fun is primary goal - best racing game on the PC that compares to the good old N64 Mario Kart  Cons: - I'll have to think of some.. it doesn't support webcams to record your friends face just when you grappled them to their death

column3: Absolute fantastic game. I was sceptical at first because Haemimont Games from my perspective completely messed up Tropico 5 with unnecessary Multiplayer-Capabilities which simplified the singleplayer-experience to such an extent that i had no fun playing it anymore.  But here they delivered.  30 and way more hours easily can go into one map. There is a little bit need for micromanagement (assigning drones and carrying ressources around in the early game) which can be a little bit tedious after a while but all other parts of the game are mostly completely automatic.  The production lines are clever
column5: the dome-principle is suprisingly funny and also the different story lines are really catching.  I don't regret paying full price for it and i hope there will be a lot more content coming soon without making the game too easy.  You should absolutely get this if you love agent based simulation/colonybuilding games with heavy focus on ressources and productionlines like Gnomoria
column6: Tropico3+4 and so on.  Edit: After reading through the plenty negative reviews here i can only sum up it as mostly misunderstanding the core mechanics of the game. People complain about colonists dying on the way between domes or drones not delivering ressources on long range. These are hardships which are embedded in the game and can be overcome with technology a bit later.  It's sad that this masterpiece get's downvoted so much and i hope the devs don't change core mechanics overhasty based on these critiques. Imho simply giving colonists the ability to use services in other domes would make the game way too easy and i actually think that building somewhat specialized domes in different configs & fulfill all necessary needs of the residents is the key point here which makes the dome-principle actually somewhat challenging and interesting.

column11: with many more different buildings in the towns. The vehicle models are really well done
column12: and they become dirty and rusty over time. Distant scenery blends better into the background with a misty effect.  The most significant change is that they've done away with the 20 minute rule and replaced it with catchment areas
column13: which is probably more familiar in these types of games. Journeys can be of any length now
column14: but passengers still prefer quicker transport. With freight it doesn't matter so much
column15: especially with ships that can carry huge amounts of cargo but travel very slowly.  Along with that
column16: resources and products no longer move on their own
column17: instead you have to transport everything yourself and place stations in appropriate catchment areas to ensure that everything gets delivered to the right places. Industries now have more complex resource requirements. If part of the supply chain is missing it will grind to a halt. This makes the game more challenging compared to Train Fever
column18: in which you could provide partial transport routes and the AI would automatically fill in the gaps.  In keeping with the more complex industries
column19: there are now six different types of products that need to be transported to towns
column20: three to the commercial districts and three to the industrial districts. This makes things even more complex since you need to use more depots to ensure the town is well supllied
column21: although you apparently only need to supply one industrial and one commercial product (in addition to passenger transport) to help cities grow

column3: The game features three short campaigns (11 scenarios total) at various difficulties
column4: plus five sandbox maps; there are no random maps to extend the content. The goal is to make money by collecting resources
column5: transporting those resources to factories to produce goods
column6: then selling those goods. There are some multi-step production chains in the game (iron + oil > plastic + steel + engine > mower) that add complexity and require planning. However
column7: it is extremely difficult to turn a profit early on in each campaign scenario (the sandbox maps have infinite money)
column8: as goods do not earn enough money to offset the expensive monthly maintenance costs for the factories and mines required to make those goods. Oligopoly is a potentially interesting economic strategy game with intricate production chains ruined by poor early game balance in the campaign mode.   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7lx6HjTjOfU

column3: The game features a campaign that consists of a series of semi-random scenarios where you must construct defenses and and army to fend off enemies that will appear after a set period of time; once you lose
column4: you have to start over from the beginning so there is only one saved game slot. Workers are assigned to collect resources
column7: or constitute your army. Town size can be increased by building houses with wells nearby
column8: and food must be produced every four turns to support your population. Random events

column3: Pros:   - A return to Dark Souls 1-type of exploration. Relies less on connected smaller areas like Dark Souls 2 and 3 but instead you have a very large enviroment to explore in which you unlock shortcuts to make traversing it quicker as you go. I very much prefer this style
column4: so it is a big plus.   - Enjoyable and meaty melee combat. I daresay it is even better than Dark Souls in some regards
column5: especially when it comes to the bigger and heavier stuff which feel properly impactful and while still slow they flow a lot better than the Greatweapons of Dark Souls.   - Controls perfectly fine with mouse and keyboard. We all know how notoriously bad the Dark Souls-series is on this point
column6: but The Surge definitely pulls it off flawlessly.   - Runs perfectly fine
column7: even on my gaming laptop which is in the middle-ground between "Minimum" and "Recommended" specs.   - POISE! PRAISE THE SUN! The type of exo-skeleton rig you are wearing has stat akin to Poise in Dark Souls
column8: only it actually matters - a lot! When you are wearing the lighter and more agile rigs
column9: you are often sent flying into the air if you are unfortunate enough to get hit by an enemy with a heavy weapon. Wearing the beefiest rigs will not only reduce the damage taken
column10: but keep your feet firmly planted on the ground!  Cons:   - No character creation whatsoever. Now this could be excused if the main character was written in such a way that his set of characteristics were central to the plot
column11: but not as much. There is one spoilerific characteristic he has at the start of the game
column12: but that could easily be given to anyone else. The role he plays could be filled by a myriad of different people.   - No online component whatsoever. Whether you loved it or hated it
column13: the multiplayer aspect is a huge part of the Soulslike-experience and it is definitely noticable in it's absence.   - Retains the dumbest gimmick from Lords of The Fallen: You won't get the "proper" boss weapon unless you defeat the boss while meeting a specific condition. There is no way to know what that condition is in-game as you are fighting them
column14: forcing you to either spoil the game for yourself by Googling all the bosses and what to do or to miss out on the good version of their weapon. While there is NG+ to let you fight them again
column15: the bosses can't be re-fought in your current NG.  Overall I'd still recommend the game because I feel the positives heavily

column3: It really pains me to leave a negative review on this. The art design and assets are top-notch and reeks W40K out of every orifice. Unfortunately the game itself isn't anywhere near as polished to the point of frustration.   - No dedicated servers. Matchmaker displays no ping or useful information whatsoever to tell you the quality of the host. Oh and if you disconnect
column4: crash or the host leaves you lose all progress/rewards. Not a good combo.   - Class information is impossible to find unless you know exactly where to look. In fact there is only one screen that displays what the various class abilities actually do. What screen you ask? The in-game loadout. Yes
column5: you actually have to start up a match if you want to read about the abilities! Furthermore this information is poorly displayed. You'd think you'd just see the class abilities and their icons and hover the mouse over them or something
column7: they're hidden under some kind of awkward "level up" system.   - Rewards are given out in a Lootbox(TM) fashion. Of course
column8: you don't have to buy them with money or anything but Lootboxes(TM) with a random reward for each level-up is a horrid way to hand out rewards even if you don't have to pay for it. I've not gotten a single useful thing for any of the classes I prefer. Woopee.   - No Single Player "level replay system". The campaign features various collectibles and not being able to easily select and replay a beaten Chapter is asenine
column9: quite frankly. You have to start the Campaign over entirely if you miss any of them since the game only has a few save slots and overwrites them with each new Chapter.

column10: can be attached to tanks to achieve the levels required by its inhabitants. Staff members will automatically feed the fish
column12: and keep the aquarium clean. Money is earned by having popular animals on display and by selling food
column14: and souvenirs. Animals also provide research points used to unlock new animals and equipment. column20: but this still requires careful expansion and resource usage until you discover those key locations. There is a significant amount of waiting for resources to accumulate (especially if your network is inefficient

Killing Floor 2 is a sequel to the popular and successful Killing Floor 1. Keep in mind that Killing Floor 2 is in early access and has yet to receive a full release. Many players from the previous title may know that some of the new features of Killing Floor 2 included sprinting and crosshair
column4: which may come as a disappointment. While I personally do not believe this should be an issue at all for both veteran and new players
column5: it does remove the aspect of having your knife out to run quicker.  About the  graphics  - there is no doubt that there is a big improvement. The game has updated graphics and textures which look significantly better than they did before.   There are 10  waves  and on the 11th wave you have to fight against a boss (either the Patriarch or Hans Volter for now). By the end of your tenth wave the map you¡¯re surviving appears splattered in blood from each shot you make. It¡¯s a good feature and definitely adds atmosphere to the chaos.   The first Killing Floor provided a selection of 7  perks . Killing Floor 2¡¯s Early Access contains 9 perks for now - Berserker

column3: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_woRBknbp8M   Ys VIII: Lacrimosa of Dana has you participate in the story of Adol and Dana
column5: while being able to alternate between them and a multitude of other characters in order to unravel and experience a deep and memorable plot involving the fate of the world. The cursed Seiren Island is an open world environment you can roam while taking down various monsters and enemies. Players meet new friends along with exploring and collecting materials for use in crafting healing items and stronger weapons.  The game opens with you
column9: which sadly doesn¡¯t get to the destination he was headed for. The player crashes near an unknown island (called the Isle of Seiren)
column10: where they struggle to survive and unearth many mysteries while saving people scattered around different locations.     -- POSITIVES --    Dual story-lines and emotional journey The majority of the time you are in control of Adol
column11: but there¡¯s a period of the story-line where you go travel through time in order to relive Dana¡¯s life that led to her becoming the Maiden of the Forest. This adds to the backstory and depth of the plot
column12: making the world feel detailed and fleshed out as it allows you to play it rather than simply explain Dana's backstory through dialogue. Throughout the whole playthrough
column13: the plot evoked many emotions that were flowing within me. Whether it would be happiness to the extreme or the contrary being extreme sadness. The story in this game provides you with a beautiful journey and emotional roller-coaster.   Endearing characters  You¡¯ll meet a wide range of characters
column14: from ones you want to hug to others which you want to punch in the face. Normally
column15: you¡¯d wish the annoying characters would not exist but Ys VIII does a great job of eventually making you attached to everyone
column16: even the ones you dislike. You learn more about them as Adol includes more into the party from either his fellow castaways or residents of the island
column17: and realize that each has something to contribute to exposition for the plot (such as Laxia
column19: providing information on Eternia).   Entrancing music The musical score in Ys VIII is simply outstanding and superb
column20: the team at Falcom and Yukihiro Jindo (the composer) has produced music which has left a mark on me months after playing. I often find myself listening to the official soundtrack and humming Dana¡¯s theme to myself when I¡¯m working on various tasks. Each song and sound really enhances the experience during gameplay and provides a perfect complement for the fantasy nature of the world.   Areas
column21: exploration and maps The Isle of Seiren doesn¡¯t skimp out with places to explore and different varieties of locations. There¡¯s one point where you can even go underwater thanks to a handy relic which takes it beyond just land-based combat. There¡¯s huge mountains
column24: boggy marshlands and so much more which really adds to the immersive nature of the open world genre. The variety of beautiful locations makes you awe in the design of it all
column26: as you can tell that the team at Falcom really wished to convey a sense of nature-meets-magic.   Longevity  Lacrimosa of Dana provides a real in-depth story and lasting narrative. Fortunately
column27: at no point did the story feel like it was dragging on and it flows nicely through the course of 30 hours or so; yet
column28: neither did it feel as if it was too short or left with any kind of cliffhanger. Ys VIII also provides a true ending for completing most of what the game has to offer
column29: so it gives you more motivation to go through every nook and cranny of the Seiren Island.   Building up a base
column31: and friend quests Upon crashing onto the Isle of Seiren
column32: you¡¯re automatically plunged into a scenario which brings you back to having nothing. With the survivors
column33: you can gather items and materials to build up the base and defenses as well as helping survivors with their quests and needs. This is a great amount of content that's been integrated into the Seiren Islands and gives the player lots to do to fill up gameplay. It wasn't too overdone and quests weren't repeated too much to make the game feel padded and instead felt organic as any hero adventurer traveling through a fantasy universe would since helping villagers and solving mysteries.    -- NEGATIVES --    Attention-seeking Raids  Every time I got engrossed and wanted to explore more
column34: the little parrot would beep up and say ¡°Alert! Alert! Camp is under attack¡±. While I believe you don¡¯t have to do them
column35: I didn¡¯t want to take any chances and found myself constantly teleporting back to a ¡®defend the base¡¯ type mini-game
column36: which I¡¯m not really a fan of. That being said
column37: if you enjoy 'defend the base' type missions
column38: this may be a positive for you. This may seem like nitpicking but when something detracts away from my exploring to do a mundane task such as this then it has a negative impact on me.   Predictability of boss fights  Every single boss fight on Ys VIII is extremely predictable in terms of when they will show up. I found myself knowing and stocking up before each and every boss on the game. This took away from the element of surprise and made sure I was fully prepared for each and every encounter as there is no point at anytime that I was caught off guard. If there were more unexpected boss battles then it would add to a more challenging gameplay instead of ensuring I was always prepared. Many players may feel like this is a sort of hand-holding.   Customization is just a palette swap  When I unlocked the tailor I got extremely excited upon hearing of character customization. Excluding the DLC
column39: the customization was a major let down as the different outfits were just color swaps of their regular uniforms. While I understand being limited on the physical side of character customization
column40: I really wish that the outfits actually changed instead of being just a simple color change.   Accidental special usage  I found that when playing on PS4
column41: to activate a special ability you need to press L1 and R1 together to activate it. The control scheme also has the dodge button on L1 and block on R1
column42: which could cause the player to accidentally activate the special at times when it's not needed. This
column44: was a bit frustrating due to the fact that special attacks took a while to build up and could also save you from potential death situations in a pinch.   PC Port Issues  While this is a more technical point to the review
column45: many people who have played the PC ported version thus far are having issues with it being buggy
column48: and not acting how it should. I¡¯m one of the fortunate few who¡¯ve encountered zero problems in either version of the title
column50: I felt it was worth noting here -- for anyone considering to get it for PC -- that many have noticed this and that it's still unknown whether it has to do with the build of your computer or some other yet-unrealized software issue.    -- CONCLUSION --   It¡¯s not often you come across masterpieces
column51: but Ys VIII: Lacrimosa of Dana is simply breathtaking and provided a voyage which has left a lifelong and emotional mark on me. There is minor annoyances to be mentioned for the game but none have seriously impacted my love for it as all the positives far outshine the negatives. From the wide range of characters to the scenery and an out-of-this-world musical score
column52: I highly recommend this as a purchase to anyone who enjoys action RPGs that contain an in-depth story and fun gameplay.  Ys VIII: Lacrimosa of Dana is simply one of the best games that I¡¯ve ever encountered and played in my life.

column3: Let me get this straight ahead and confirm that the wait for SOMA was
column5: well-worth it. Frictional delivers yet another masterpiece. I even dare say they followed the saying: ''There's always room for more.''
column6: after their fantastic Amnesia series. What we got from them here is one of those existential questioning games... combine that with horror
column8: incredible  sound effects and you get a memorable gem.  SOMA has less enemy encounters than Amnesia
column9: but I say it's for a good cause. What it lacks in terms of monsters
column10: it completely delivers with the story. I'd say they got the perfect balance between hiding and actual advancing through the events. More encounters would have made me forget about the plot and it would have gotten unimmersive. But when there is a monster showing around
column11: expect it to be a challenging part. No more hiding in a corner and waiting for it to leave as in previous games
column12: as SOMA's creatures are not just randomly going away after a while. They'll stay in your path and you have to carefully progress through the chambers and remember the map
column13: in order to get away safe and sound.  I did mention this is more of an existentional questioning game. I can't dig deeper into details on this one as it would all lead to story-breaking spoilers. Heck
column14: even the premise of it is a spoiler. All I can say is that it successfully made me question what it is to be a human and what distinguishes us from artificial intelligences --robots-- .  What I also loved about it was its length. 13 hours to finish an indie game is nothing short of amazing and I didn't even stay to read all notes and journals. I'll definitely give this game a second playthrough.  The inventory has been massively simplified since Amnesia and the sanity/health system is also changed. Looking at some monsters for too long will give away your position and health can be restored at healing places throughout the journey.  Technically speaking
column15: the game suffers from a poor optimization. I was getting massive frame drops in some places. Visually it does not excel either. But I can get past these issues coming from a small company. On the other side
column16: I haven't encountered many bugs nor grammatical errors and kudos to the developers for taking their time and patching up their game!  *End-game debate incoming (definitely spoilers ahead); please skip to next paragraph for general personal rating if you haven't completed the game yet.* The feeling that was following me up to the very end was one of d¨¦j¨¤ vu. There is another game out there that raised the exact same questioning:   The Talos Principle. Apocalypse
column17: AI that would replace the mankind and would live through a new aeon? These two games are as if set in the same universe. If you put away the gameplay of them

column19: a group of scientists work in projecting it on digital chips. The Talos Principle follows a similar path
column20: with one AI already constructed and left in sleep mode until it proves that it acts and  thinks  humanlike. In both games you are playing as a virtual mind placed into a carcass
column21: in order to continue human legacy. Could these two games be set in the same world? The similarities between them are astonishing. Also

column23: where he is duplicated and a part of him remains alone for an eternity on a wasted planet
column24: while the other rests forever in the ARK
column25: on a digital island.. The main character could very well not be the first copy of his brain awoken.      Pros:   + Excellent plot and an overall amazing storyline. column3: The idea  What a brilliant concept to offer gamers a simulation of the gaming industry

column11: but I have yet to see a strategy game where this is not the case
column12: so this is forgivable.  A big minus
column14: is the fact that you do not get to command your troops in battle. This feature
column16: was the biggest disappointment for me. It all plays out automatically
column17: with a step-by-step battle report on the side (which impairs my immersion
column18: because it is stat-related and technical). You cannot even give basic commands like "retreat" or "defensive stance". Neither can you influence the battle formation
column20: that can lead to archers being useless because your own ranks in front of them prevent enemies from getting into shooting range. Maybe
column21: the developer wanted to spare the player too much micromanagement
column22: but this could have easily been solved by making such interventions optional. Also
column23: I do not understand why castles and watchtowers are all represented exactly the same. At least
column24: you don't have to watch every skirmish play out
column25: but can increase speed or skip to the final result
column26: which I ended up doing regularly after an hour.   Verdict  This quite decent retro indie game does not actually offer a lot of production value
column27: but it manages to stimulate your imagination to make up narratives while you experience a minimalistic strategy game with an exceptional variety of different units. 6.5/10.

column3: This is my favourite fantasy RPG
column4: despite all of its little flaws - the freedom of movement
column5: quest choices and role-play options is unmatched by any of its competitors as far as I know. The variety of activities as well as the depth of lore is simply inspiring. Some people wrote that the predecessor Oblivion was a better RPG - I played both
column6: and I disagree. The good things of Oblivion are included in Skyrim
column7: but the graphics and gameplay have been improved greatly.  I literally spent weeks of my lifetime in Skyrim with several playthroughs: I was - a Cyrodiilic vagabond who got caught by border patrol and almost executed on suspicion of treason
column8: but miraculously saved and personally impressed by a Nord officer in the ranks of the Imperial army. I enlisted as a recruit
column9: took part in the civil war in the province and went from a lightly armed ranger to a distinguished officer in priceless heavy plate
column10: a one-man-army roaming the land and destroying anyone and anything that threatens the peaceful subjects of the Emperor in defiance of His laws - all while entertaining a passionate interest in Dwarven ruins and artifacts. - a Reachman from Markarth who got himself into a conflict with organised crime
column11: had to flee from the city and learn how to survive in the wilderness
column12: became a werewolf and follower of Hircine
column13: the Daedric Prince of the Hunt. Hunting animals
column14: highwaymen and soldiers of the Imperial and Thalmor occupation force proved to be the mere training phase for the real "game": giants
column15: legendary dragons and vampire lords became my prey and worthy sacrifices for my Daedric Master. - a Dark Elf from Morrowind who wandered to the ruins of Winterhold to study at the famous college there
column16: become a master of alchemy and destruction magic
column17: compare strength with ancient and powerful dragonpriests and collect souls for his mistress Azura. - an Argonian worker from Windhelm who had enough of discrimination and daily humiliation by the Nords
column18: made his way to Riften and became a member of the Thieves guild
column19: was then abducted by the Dark Brotherhood and forced into their service - which they regretted when facing their utter destruction. Yet
column20: I felt my soul had been corrupted by the thought of gaining power exploiting others even down to their lives
column22: I became a vampire and terrorized the land with my growing abilities
column23: amassing incredible wealth.  These are only a few examples of the stories that I invented and experienced playing this game
column24: and for giving me the material to incite my imagination in this intensity
column25: I am grateful to Bethesda and forgive them all the bugs that occasionally occurred.  I give this game a heartfelt 9

column4: I ran this remake on a Win10 PC with a NVIDIA GTX 745
column5: and neither did I have problems starting the game nor did it crash once during my 2 hours (short) playthrough.   Remake nostalgia  I enjoyed it very much. During the late 80s
column6: I played the original Vermeer on my Schneider CPC6128. I was pleasantly surprised  about this rejuvenated version
column8: the nicely executed intro and the stylish background music (one for each city you can travel to). Everyone who shares my aforementioned experience with the original should have a fresh look. Gamers who do not have this predisposition for nostalgia might find the game a little simplistic
column9: but it feels quite relaxing nevertheless.   Gameplay  The goal is to collect famous paintings to please your wealthy uncle
column10: competing with some of your relatives (AI or hotseat multiplayer) for his inheritance. Most of those pieces of art are bought in auction houses all over Europe and the USA
column11: and in order to do that
column12: you need to earn money as a planter in Asia
column17: tobacco as well as silk) and sell them on commodity markets in London and New York. Forward contracts with higher profits
column19: special events and expeditions to exotic places spice up this routine between simple economic simulation and educational collect quest. During the short game
column20: it did not become boring. I am not sure how it would feel to play the long version in one session though.   I did not encounter any bugs. It seemed a little confusing at first when the amount of my available funds was automatically increased or decreased (when I ran into debt
column21: the game decided for me that I needed to take a higher bank loan)
column22: and the rules what you can and cannot buy when your cash runs out are a little arbitrary (crop transfer yes
column25: expeditions no...) - coming from the original game where you could not even buy a train ticket without a positive cash balance
column26: I understand that the developers of the remake wanted to avoid the (formerly common) situation that the player got stuck in the middle of nowhere
column27: waiting for a random money gift from your uncle for travel expenses.  I cannot write this review without mentioning the beautiful replicas of the paintings and their informative descriptions you can read by inspecting them. I love it when a game has some real-life educational value in addition to the good entertainment.   Verdict  The original classic has been modernized and presented in a very appealing way. The game is stable
column28: and it is not expensive. I give it a 7.5/10 and recommend it to Vermeer veterans
column29: friends of the simulation genre who want to try something not too complicated
column30: and to culture vultures who appreciate the art theme.
